Begin forwarded message:

From: Robin Willis Beck Date: September 26, 2023 at 10:41:15?AM EDTTo: access@louderthanlifefestival.comSubject: Re: ADA

?I do not want to come off the wrong way but need to know if there is some type of insurance company that I can contact for this issue. I?m already missing my second day of work and can not return until I?ve seen an orthopedic surgeon. I did not get a chance to even ask anyone that helped me. 

 

 

Thank You!

Robin Willis Beck

1214 Pigeon Pass Rd

Louisville KY 40213

502-260-2827

 

On Sep 23, 2023, at 1:29?AM, access@louderthanlifefestival.com wrote:

?

Hello,

 

First, we are sorry to hear about your experience. We will make sure your concerns get to festival operations. Second, since it is medically necessary are able to bring in a chair. Show this message to Security if you have any issues. If you do come, and do bring a chair, please bring a small foldable, collapsible camping style chair. 

?

Fahntoosh EnterprisesGuest Services, on Behalf of Danny Wimmer Presents 

On Fri, 22 Sep at 8:42 PM , Robin Willis Beck wrote: 

I broke my ankle Thursday evening while walking to the bathrooms where there is a ridge between the grass and concrete with no lighting or paint to show the hazard. I am including 2 pictures below to show where I am talking about as well as my discharge papers from the ER. Now I?m going to miss the next 3 days. How do I get in on crutches and with such limited space in the ADA area what am I supposed to do now? I paid for all 4 days and got to see 1 day. I am not permitted to bring a seat into the very place that landed me with a broken ankle with crutches because the ADA section is so small????? I have came to your concert for so many years that I can not even describe the amount of disappointment in this situation that I NEVER ASKED TO BE IN!!!!! I don?t know why I?m bothering even sending this because I know I will never get a response.Thank You!Robin Willis Beck1214 Pigeon Pass RdLouisville KY 40213502-260-2827

132712:2023007
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin Willis Beck – Premise-09-21-2023. Initial client contact concerns Robin Willis Beck, who was injured at the Louder Than Life festival on the evening of September 21, 2023. She states she broke her ankle while walking to the festival bathrooms, describing a hazard where grass meets concrete along a ridge with no lighting or paint to warn attendees. She attached two pictures and her ER discharge papers. Robin notes she will miss the next three days of the festival, having paid for all four days but only attending one day. She planned to proceed with crutches and was concerned about space in the ADA area and was not permitted to bring a seat into that area because it is very small. She provided her contact details: 1214 Pigeon Pass Rd, Louisville, KY 40213, 502-260-2827. A case reference in the record appears as 132712:2023007.

On September 22, 2023 at 8:42 PM, Robin emailed access@louderthanlifefestival.com describing that she broke her ankle Thursday evening and detailing the hazard near the restrooms. On September 23, 2023 at 1:29 AM, the festival responded: “Hello, First, we are sorry to hear about your experience. We will make sure your concerns get to festival operations. Second, since it is medically necessary are able to bring in a chair. Show this message to Security if you have any issues. If you do come, and do bring a chair, please bring a small foldable, collapsible camping style chair.” This guidance was issued by Fahntoosh Enterprises Guest Services, on behalf of Danny Wimmer Presents.

In a separate exchange, on September 26, 2023 at 10:41:15 AM EDT, Robin sent another message to access@louderthanlifefestival.com asking whether there is any insurance company she can contact regarding the issue. She explained that she is already missing her second day of work and cannot return until she has seen an orthopedic surgeon, and she noted that she did not get a chance to ask anyone who helped her.

On November 7, 2023, the file shows an email chain involving attorney Bryce Koon of Whaley Law Firm. At 2:10 PM Eastern Time, Bryce sent to Robin’s case file with the subject FW: ADA. Earlier that same day, at 1:22 PM, Robin sent to Bryce a message with the subject Fwd: ADA and a simple “Thank You!” The forwarded content includes the September 26 and September 23 communications described above, as well as the September 22 message detailing the injury, the ADA seating concerns, and the reference 132712:2023007. The record also reflects that the November 7 exchange was part of the ongoing ADA-related communications.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

I need a contact for whoever you have insurance with for the event for bodily damage?? I AM NOT NEEDING A CONTACT FOR TICKET INSURANCE! I stated that repeatedly in the last 3 emails!!!!! I?m not asking for a refund? I need to know the contact info for the insurance company that you use for injuries occurring during the concert. I never asked for a refund? I need to know who to contact because I have hospital and medical bills along with now lost wages due to either there being no markings to show that there is a major drop off from the grass onto the concrete or at the very least lighting so you could see the drop off that broke my ankle?

 

 

Thank You!

1214 Pigeon Pass Rd

Louisville KY 40213

Dancel E (Front Gate Tickets NA) 

Sep 29, 2023, 17:58 GMT+1 

Hello Robin, Thanks for reaching out to us about a refund. I understand that you want to get contact information about insurance.Upon checking here on your tickets there was no ticket insurance purchase or included on this order. And please note that all sales are final, and policies set forth by Event Providers generally prohibit us from issuing exchanges or refunds after a ticket has been purchased. Please see our Terms Of Use & Sale for more details. And for any exemptions kindly reach out to the festival info@louderthanlife.com. If your event has been canceled, postponed rescheduled, or moved to a new location, and refunds have been approved by the Event Provider, we will notify you by email, to the email address on file, with the refund or exchange procedures provided by the Event Provider. Please see our FAQ for more information. Questions? Please reply to this email, or get answers right now. 

Sincerely,Dancel EFront Gate Tickets Fan Support

 

Robin L Willis Beck 

Sep 29, 2023, 09:05 GMT+1 

I broke my ankle this year on the first night due to lake off lighting in an area that changed from grass to concrete. I have a picture of the 6-7 inch drop off. I contacted you guys to see how I would go about getting into the concert for the remaining 3 days due to being in a wheel chair and crutches. Someone did respond to let me know that I would use their reply to get back into the concert if there were issues with security. I sent a reply to ask for the insurance contact but no one has responded. I even order my tickets as did my family for 2024 already this morning. So 6 people including me and my husband are coming in 2024 so it?s not like I?m hating on you guys for this happening. However there being no light or markings to warn that there was about a 6-7 inch drop off I fell due to it and now my ankle is broken. I need insurance contact information because my insurance is wanting me to get it. Attaching the pictures below.

[9PVL01-7E7KR]
episodes.natural_language:
This case note concerns client Robin Willis Beck (Premise case date: 09-21-2023). On September 29, 2023, Robin contacted Front Gate Tickets about insurance information following an injury at the Louder Than Life festival. She reported breaking her ankle on the first night, attributing the injury to poor lighting and a hazard where grass gave way to concrete, describing a drop-off of six to seven inches. She stated there was no signage or lighting to warn of the drop-off and indicated hospital and medical bills as well as lost wages. Robin asserted she could prove the injury with pictures, paperwork, and witness statements, and she requested the contact information for the event’s bodily-injury insurance (not ticket insurance). She provided her address (1214 Pigeon Pass Rd, Louisville, KY 40213) and phone number (502-260-2827) and noted that she had attached photos to her message (IMG_9777.jpeg and IMG_8473.jpeg). She also indicated intentions related to returning for the remaining days and to 2024 events, and she sought the appropriate insurance contact rather than a refund.

Front Gate Tickets replied multiple times that there was no ticket insurance purchased or included with her order. In their replies, they advised Robin to refer to information about insurance and to contact the festival’s general information for exemptions (festival info@louderthanlife.com). They also referenced the standard policy language: that all sales are final and that refunds or exchanges are typically prohibited by ticket-provider terms; exemptions could be pursued by contacting the festival information email. The responses came with timestamps on September 29, 2023, including 09:05 GMT+1 (Robin’s initial inquiry about insurance), 17:58 GMT+1 (Dancel E’s note that there was no ticket insurance), 18:06 GMT+1 (Robin’s clarification that she was not seeking a refund and that she needed the event’s insurance contact for bodily injury), 20:30 GMT+1 (Dancel E’s reminder about no ticket insurance and the instruction to contact festival info@louderthanlife.com), and 22:20 GMT+1 (Robin reiterating that she needed the insurance contact and not ticket insurance). The final note from Front Gate Tickets on that day, 23:06 GMT+1, stated that the request for exemptions should go through the festival’s own channels and again confirmed the absence of ticket insurance.

In addition to the above, the message thread included an instruction line within the forwarded thread: “Your request (32542769) has been updated. To add additional comments, reply to this email,” reflecting ongoing correspondence. The thread culminated with Robin sending a forward of the entire Insurance Info exchange to her attorney, Bryce Koon, on November 7, 2023 at 1:23 PM. In that forwarding, she included the prior chain, with the surrounding headers showing the outreach from Front Gate Tickets dated September 29, 2023, and the earlier responses. The forward’s header shows the sending attorney contact: Bryce Koon (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) to RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, dated November 7, 2023 at 14:10:08 -0500. Robin’s message to the attorney included a brief “Thank You!” and indicated it was a forward of the insurance information.

Attachments noted in the original thread were IMG_9777.jpeg and IMG_8473.jpeg. The record also includes the line “trigger_logic_for_fgt” at the end of the capture. Overall, the notes document Robin’s request for the insurance contact related to bodily injury from the Louder Than Life event, the vendor’s confirmation that no ticket insurance existed and guidance to pursue festival-provided insurance information, her insistence that this is not a ticket-insurance issue, and the subsequent forwarding of the entire exchange to her attorney for potential legal consideration.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

__FW: Robin Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents and Kentucky State Fair Board, et al__
From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Thu, 25 Jan 2024 15:09:30 -0500

 

 

From: Aaron WhaleySent: Thursday, January 25, 2024 3:08 PMTo: Kevin ProphetCc: bryce@whaleylawfirm.comSubject: Re: Robin Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents and Kentucky State Fair Board, et al

 

I am fine with a 14 day extension. 

 

On Thu, Jan 25, 2024 at 3:07?PM Kevin Prophet wrote:

H&W Risk Management is the claims administrator for ACE American Insurance Company, Kentucky State Fair Board’s (KSFB)general liability insurer.  We are in receipt of the Robin Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al Complaint.  Our understanding is the incident arises out of your client’s attendance at the Louder Than Life Festival promoted and presented by Wimmer.  This is our first notice of the incident so we do not yet have a claim file set up in order to provide a claim number at this time.  I will certainly provide your office with the claim number once the file is established.

 

I kindly ask that you grant an extension of time to allow us time to review the applicable contracts, consider any appropriate tender of defense, and to refer the matter to defense counsel to respond to the Complaint.  I am currently attending to my father in hospice so I am limited as to promptness in communications.  I do check my emails periodically and can schedule a time to speak by phone.  Please confirm via email your agreement to an extension of time to respond to the Complaint.

 

Kevin D. Prophet, MBA, AIC  ¦  Claims Supervisor  

913-676-9284 direct   ¦   

kevin.prophet@hwins.com 

 

H&W Risk Management  

4300 Shawnee Mission Parkway, Fairway, KS 66205

913.432.4400 main  ¦  www.hwins.com

 

INSURING YOUR SUCCESS 

 

H&W Risk Management Administers Claims on Behalf of ACE-American Insurance Company

Haas & Wilkerson | CA License # 0556737

Claim Manager I CA License # 4256968

 

 

 

  

 Insurance coverage or changes to coverage requested via text message, voice mail, or email is not legally binding until you have received direct confirmation from an agent or licensed employee of H & W Risk Management or its affiliates.This transmission is intended for the use of the individual or entity to which it is addressed and may contain information that is privileged, confidential and exempt from disclosure under applicable law.  If the reader of this transmission is not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify the sender by reply transmission and delete or destroy the message without copying or disclosing it. 

  

 

-- 

Aaron Whaley

Whaley Law Firm

712 Lyndon Ln

Louisville, KY 40222

502-583-4022
episodes.natural_language:
In the case of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, and the Kentucky State Fair Board, et al., dated January 25, 2024, counsel for Robin Willis Beck exchanged emails about an extension of time to respond to the complaint. The matter arises from Beck’s attendance at the Louder Than Life Festival promoted and presented by Danny Wimmer Presents. H&W Risk Management acts as the claims administrator for ACE American Insurance Company, the general liability insurer for the Kentucky State Fair Board (KSFB). This was the insurer’s first notice of the incident, and, at that moment, no claim file had been set up nor a claim number issued. The insurer indicated that it would provide the claim number once the file was established and requested an extension of time to review the applicable contracts, consider a tender of defense, and refer the matter to defense counsel to respond to the Complaint. Kevin D. Prophet, MBA, AIC, Claims Supervisor for H&W Risk Management, wrote that he was attending to his father in hospice, which limited promptness in communications, but he could check email and schedule a call. He asked that the recipient confirm via email agreement to an extension of time to respond to the Complaint. Prophet provided his direct line (913-676-9284), email (kevin.prophet@hwins.com), and the address for H&W Risk Management (4300 Shawnee Mission Parkway, Fairway, KS 66205), along with the main line (913.432.4400) and the firm’s website (www.hwins.com). He also noted that H&W Risk Management administers claims on behalf of ACE-American Insurance Company and included the relevant affiliations (Haas & Wilkerson; CA License numbers 0556737 and 4256968). The communication contained the standard disclaimer that insurance coverage or changes to coverage requested via text, voicemail, or email is not legally binding until confirmed by a licensed agent or employee, and that the transmission is confidential and privileged; dissemination to non‑intended recipients is prohibited.

Later that day, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm replied that he was fine with a 14-day extension. The thread shows the exchange proceeding to an agreed extension of time to respond to the Complaint. The emails included the forwarded header from Bryce Koon at Whaley Law Firm, with the recipient address for Robin Willis Beck, and there were references to the ongoing settlement-defense coordination among the plaintiff’s counsel and the insurer’s claims administrator. The correspondence also contains the Whaley Law Firm contact details: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022, and the sender’s signature.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

The note concerns an extension to plead for all defendants, with communications in the case referencing the Jefferson Circuit Court civil claims brought by Beck. The email thread includes participants from Whaley Law Firm and Reminger Co., L.P.A., along with the Robin Willis Beck Filevine project email address.

On March 4, 2024, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., wrote Bryce Whaley at Whaley Law Firm (and cc’d Aaron Whaley, Karen Hedgecock, and the Robin Willis Beck Filevine address) regarding an extension to plead for all defendants. Lowery explained that he had been retained to represent Danny Wimmer Presents in relation to Beck’s civil claims in the Jefferson Circuit Court. He noted that co-defendant KSFB and its employees had submitted a defense tender demand onto DWP, and that DWP was currently evaluating it. He requested a global twenty-five day extension, moving the responsive pleading and/or motions deadline to Friday, March 29, 2024, to allow time to address the tenders and determine how to move forward with representations. He asked to be advised if the extension was agreeable or if there were questions or concerns, and expressed willingness to discuss the case further prior to tender outcomes.

A follow-up message from Lowery was sent on March 7, 2024, at 9:04 AM. In that note, he addressed Bryce, asking whether the extension would be agreeable to Beck’s client, noting that the extension offered to various adjusters was set to lapse the next day, and thus requesting consideration of the extension request.

Later that same day, March 7, 2024, at 10:35:23 AM (-0500), Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm replied that Beck’s client was agreeable to the extension. Whaley’s message was sent to Steven Lowery with Bryce Whaley and Karen Hedgecock cc’d, and included Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine project email address. The reply was part of the same email thread discussing the extension of time to plead for all defendants in Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al. The message included standard firm contact details and a confidentiality disclaimer, consistent with the chain of correspondence on this matter.

__RE: re Tender Result, Req for Extension and for KSFB Dismissal - Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al__
From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [SLowery@reminger.com](mailto:SLowery@reminger.com) Steven B. Lowery, [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) Aaron Whaley
Cc: [KHedgecock@reminger.com](mailto:KHedgecock@reminger.com) Karen Hedgecock
Date: Fri, 22 Mar 2024 11:52:50 -0400

Good afternoon Steven, 

 

Thank you for your email and for keeping us informed of the recent developments regarding the acceptance of the defense tender by Danny Wimmer Presents (DWP) and its employees under the client umbrella of Reminger. We appreciate your efforts in facilitating this process and are agreeable to the seven-day extension. 

 

Additionally, we are agreeable to dismissal without prejudice of the government Defendants, with the understanding that the claims will be preserved, and the defendants may potentially be brought back into this litigation subject to discovery of new information. That being said, I would prefer to receive an Answer on behalf of Danny Wimmer Presents prior to the filing of any Agreed Order of Dismissal. 

 

Thank you for your attention to these matters, and we look forward to resolving this issue in an efficient and cooperative manner.

 

 

W. Bryce Koon, Esq.The Whaley Law Firm 712 Lyndon Lane

Louisville, KY 40222Phone: (502) 365-5043Fax: (502) 364-9363

 

This electronic message is intended only for the named recipient. It may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information. If you have received this message or any attachment in error, you are instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and advise in this regard, no waiver of any privilege shall be applicable, and you are instructed that you should not use the information contained herein or forward it to any third person not intended to receive it. 

 

From: Steven B. LowerySent: Friday, March 22, 2024 11:35 AMTo: Aaron Whaley; Bryce KoonCc: Karen HedgecockSubject: re Tender Result, Req for Extension and for KSFB Dismissal - Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al

 

Counsel,

 

Please note that Danny Wimmer Presents has accepted the defense tender of KSFB and its employees. As such, all defendants will be under the client umbrella of Reminger. Given this development, I would like to request one last good faith extension of seven days, until Friday April 5, 2024, to provide responses for the defendants to your clients complaint. Please let me know if this is agreeable and I thank you for your amenability to date regarding our responses to allow me to get the tender issue sorted out.

 

As to Kentucky State Fair Board, I want to make a formal request that it and its employees be released from the subject lawsuit. KSFB is a governmental entity enshrined in state statute, See KRS 247.100, et seq, and operates as a political subdivision of the Commonwealth of Kentucky. Mr. Hensler and Mr. McCoy are Executive members of the KSFB governmental staff, and their functions as outlined in your clients complaint are undisputably discretionary in nature. To the extent your client feels it has a separate and distinct claim of civil negligence against KSFB and its employees, she should proceed against those entities by filing a claim in the Board of Claims. Otherwise, governmental immunity and qualified official immunity will bar the claims against KSFB and its employees in the circuit court. As to voluntary dismissal, KSFB and its employees would be amenable to a dismissal without prejudice.

 

Your client’s complaint facially alleges an injury sustained while a patron of Louder Than Life, hosted by Danny Wimmer Presents, and appears to allege that she sustained injury while within the portion of premises leased and controlled by Danny Wimmer. As such, DWP will be preparing an Answer to the Complaint and will be the primary party engaging in civil discovery with your client. 

 

Please review at your convenience the above requests and let me know if you have any questions or concerns that I may be able to address. Happy to jump on the phone and discuss these matters in more detail. Thank you both for your attention to these matters.

 

Best,

 

  My Bio |   Website  |  vCard 

T? 502-625-7306F? 502-589-5436M 703-517-9480 www.reminger.com

Steven B. Lowery, Esq.Reminger Co., LPA SLowery@reminger.com730 West Main StreetSuite 300Louisville, KY 40202

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al., Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023, the client is Robin Willis Beck. On March 22, 2024, a series of emails was exchanged between counsel regarding the tender result, a request for a short extension, and the potential dismissal of the Kentucky State Fair Board (KSFB) defendants. Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., LPA, sent to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon (with Karen Hedgecock CC’d) a message noting that Danny Wimmer Presents had accepted the defense tender for KSFB and its employees, meaning all defendants would be under the Reminger client umbrella. He requested a final good-faith extension of seven days, until Friday, April 5, 2024, to provide responses to the defendants’ complaints, and asked for confirmation that this extension was agreeable. He also stated that he formally requested the release of KSFB and its employees from the subject lawsuit, explaining that KSFB is a governmental entity created by state statute (KRS 247.100, et seq.), operates as a political subdivision of the Commonwealth of Kentucky, and that Mr. Hensler and Mr. McCoy are executive members of KSFB’s governmental staff. He argued that the functions described in the client’s complaint are discretionary in nature and that, if the client has a separate and distinct civil negligence claim against KSFB and its employees, the proper route would be to file a claim with the Board of Claims; otherwise governmental immunity and qualified official immunity would bar those claims in circuit court. He indicated KSFB and its employees would be amenable to dismissal without prejudice. He also noted that the plaintiff’s complaint facially alleges an injury sustained while a patron of Louder Than Life, the event hosted by Danny Wimmer Presents, and appears to allege injury within the portion of premises leased and controlled by Danny Wimmer; accordingly, DWP would be preparing an Answer to the Complaint and would be the primary party engaging in civil discovery with the client. He closed by inviting the recipients to review the requests and to discuss any questions by phone, thanking them for their attention.

Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, replied later that same day, acknowledging Steven’s email and expressing agreement with the seven-day extension. He stated agreement to a dismissal without prejudice of the government Defendants, with the understanding that the claims would be preserved and that the defendants could potentially be brought back into the litigation subject to discovery of new information. However, Koon indicated a preference to receive an Answer on behalf of Danny Wimmer Presents prior to filing any Agreed Order of Dismissal. He concluded by thanking them for their attention and signing with his contact details for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363. The message emphasized confidentiality and included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer, stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain privileged information, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or forward the information. The notice also stated that the email had been scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd.

The communications included the original email from Steven B. Lowery dated Friday, March 22, 2024 at 11:35 a.m., to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon with Karen Hedgecock CC’d, and the subject line re Tender Result, Req for Extension and for KSFB Dismissal - Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, LLC, et al. Lowery’s message outlined the tender acceptance by DWP, the need for an extension to respond to the complaint, and the request to release KSFB and its employees from the litigation, citing KSFB’s statutory status and the immunity issues that would arise if it remained a party. It also described the expectation that Danny Wimmer Presents would file an Answer and would lead civil discovery in relation to the client’s claims.

In addition to the substantive content, each email included standard confidentiality and privilege notices: The Whaley Law Firm email carried a confidential-attorney-client-privilege disclaimer, instructing that the message is intended only for the named recipient, that disclosure or use by others is prohibited, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or forward the information. The Reminger email carried a similar disclaimer about confidentiality and the virus-scanning status by Mimecast Ltd.

In summary, as of March 22, 2024, the parties contemplated that Danny Wimmer Presents would absorb the defense under Reminger’s umbrella, sought a seven-day extension to respond to the complaint, and discussed the possible dismissal without prejudice of KSFB and its employees, with preservation of claims and the possibility of rejoining the litigation upon discovery. The parties also agreed—subject to receiving Danny Wimmer Presents’ Answer before any Agreed Order of Dismissal—that such an approach would proceed, and they remained open to further discussion by phone if needed.

She noted that the insured had forwarded the attached summons and complaint documents to her yesterday, and that those documents had been sent to an old address via certified mail and were received on February 5, 2024. Clark indicated she was working to assign defense on a rush assignment and observed that the effective due date for a response was Friday, February 23, 2024 (technically Sunday, February 25, 2024). She requested that the due date be extended to Friday, March 8, 2024, and asked for agreement or for another proposed date. The message included a cordial sign-off from Clark, with her pronouns listed as she/her/hers, and her contact information: direct line +1.302.553.1632, devon.clark@agcs.allianz.com, and links to Allianz’s claims resources. The signature block also listed the Allianz group of affiliates and a broad disclaimer about Allianz’s claims-promise and customer feedback.

The email thread shows an immediate response from Aaron Whaley, who replied on February 21, 2024 at 11:56 AM, “I am fine with that.” Earlier that same day, at approximately 11:53 AM, Clark had written to Aaron with the same extension request. In that earlier message, Clark reiterated the request for an extension for counsel to respond because the defense was being assigned on a rush basis, noting that the summons and complaint had been forwarded to her and were received on February 5, 2024 after being mailed to an old address. She again stated that the current due date for a response was Friday, February 23, 2024 (with the stated technical date of Sunday, February 25, 2024) and asked for a new due date of Friday, March 8, 2024, or another proposed date, pending agreement.

That message also included a confidentiality notice typical of Allianz communications: The information in the message and any accompanying files is confidential, may be legally privileged, and intended only for the named recipients; if received in error, the recipient should notify the sender and delete the material. The message footer identified the sender as Devon Clark of Allianz and included her professional title and firm information, along with Allianz’s standard disclosures and disclaimers.

The chain ends with Aaron Whaley’s brief reply agreeing to the proposed extension and with the standard signature block for Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022. The narrative also reflects the Filevine Project address listed among the To recipients: “Robin Willis Beck SF 09/21/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address.” The matter is documented in the Allianz communications as part of the claims handling process, with the parties coordinating a new response deadline in light of conflicts clearance and the recognition that summons and complaint documents were received at a non-current address.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023
Client: Robin Willis Beck

This is Robin Willis Beck. Your firm is handling my accident claim against Louder Than Life. The last time I spoke with anyone it was stated that you were going to file in the courts due to no one returning any information. I just wanted to see what was going on. I still can’t have my ankle treated because I would have to pay the whole bill portion that my private insurance didn’t cover and I can’t afford that at all.
(Sending request to Bryce and Sarena for client update) I called Ms Beck and let her know one of them will be contacting her - She said she is on the phone a lot - and just leave a message and she will return the call #cc
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on September 21, 2023, with Robin Willis Beck regarding an accident claim against Louder Than Life. Ms. Beck stated that our firm is handling her claim against Louder Than Life and that, during her last conversation, she was told the firm would file in court due to no one returning any information. She requested an update on the status of the matter. She also explained that she cannot obtain treatment for her ankle because she would have to pay the full portion of the bill that her private insurance did not cover, and she cannot afford that.

Internal actions included sending a request to Bryce and Sarena for a client update. I called Ms. Beck and informed her that one of them would be contacting her; she said she is on the phone a lot and asked that a message be left, noting she would return the call. #cc
episodes.author: Faye Gaither

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Called Client to confirm providers - Provided Upd on Litigation & BK working w/DC on who all will remain as Def & those who will not - Advised Recvd Answer from Danny Wimmer Presents which is Main Def - Confirmed Providers Listed - Client is unable to treat due to balance owed to Norton Ortho - Insurance did not cover enough & Client does not have $400 to pay out of pocket - Advised will discuss with AW & BK about getting her to a Provider who will treat on a lien for now - Client expressed understanding & appreciated the update 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. The initial client contact occurred on April 3, 2024, with Sarena regarding Robin Willis Beck. Sarena called the client to confirm the providers and to provide an update on the litigation and bankruptcy, noting that the bankruptcy is working with DC on who will remain as defendants and who will not. She advised that an answer had been received from Danny Wimmer Presents, which is the main defendant, and she confirmed the providers listed.

The client is currently unable to pursue treatment due to a balance owed to Norton Ortho; insurance did not cover enough and the client does not have $400 to pay out of pocket. It was advised that AW and BK would discuss getting her to a provider who will treat on a lien for now. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the update.

1. Non-united distal left fibular fracture below the tibiotalar joint with grade 3 sprain to the anterior talofibular ligament and calcaneofibular ligament.
2. Grade 1 sprain of the left deltoid ligament. 
3. Moderate tendinopathy and partial-thickness tear of the distal left posterior tibialis tendon insertion with tenosynovitis.

tendinopathy of the peroneus brevis tendon.

episodes.natural_language:

Impression: First, there is a nonunion distal left fibular fracture below the tibiotalar joint with a grade 3 sprain to the anterior talofibular ligament and the calcaneofibular ligament. Second, there is a grade 1 sprain of the left deltoid ligament. Third, there is moderate tendinopathy and a partial-thickness tear of the distal left posterior tibialis tendon insertion with tenosynovitis. Fourth, there is a longitudinal split tear with moderate tendinopathy of the peroneus brevis tendon. Fifth, there is tenosynovitis and mild tendinopathy of the peroneus longus tendon at the peroneal tubercle.

episodes.natural_language:
Case Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. On July 11, 2024, Sarena made the initial client contact with Robin Willis Beck regarding the case.

During the call, the client reported that she had received a call in June but no one returned her call, and she was unsure what JC had called her about. We advised her of the current status and discussed that she is still receiving Outstanding MB Notices from Goulds. We advised her to send us a copy of the next notice so we can address it. She appreciated the update. A client text was sent instructing her to send any further Billing Notices.

Case: Robin Willis Beck — Premise-09-21-2023. In the matter of Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, the DWP discovery to Ms. Beck is being tracked in an email thread. On August 6, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, noted that discovery had already been received and sent to the client, and that Ms. Beck had executed the authorizations and the verification page in the file. The client was planning to call later that day or the next day to review her actual responses. Sarena provided her contact information and flagged a new email address for communications.

Earlier, in the same thread, Bryce Koon forwarded a message from Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., LPA, dated July 29, 2024 at 12:01 PM, addressed to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon and copied to Karen Hedgecock. Steven stated that attached materials included DWP’s IRFPDs onto Ms. Beck, with a Word document included, and the authorizations. He noted that if Ms. Beck did not agree to authorizations for her medical and wage records, they should inform him at the earliest convenience so they could begin the subpoena process. He invited any questions or concerns. The message carried Steven Lowery’s contact details: T 502-625-7306, F 502-589-5436, M 703-517-9480, and his Reminger Co., LPA website. It included a standard confidentiality disclaimer, indicating the information was confidential and intended for the recipient(s). The communication footer identified Steven B. Lowery as an attorney with Reminger Co., LPA, located at 730 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202.

Let me know if you have any questions or concerns.” The email signature for Lowery followed, including his biographical and contact details (My Bio | Website | vCard; T 502-625-7306; F 502-589-5436; M 703-517-9480; www.reminger.com), and his firm’s address at 730 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202. The same confidentiality disclaimer appeared in this message as well.

Separately, a forward from Aaron Whaley dated September 27, 2024 at 11:51:28 GMT-04:00 summarized the exchange. The forwarded email thread began with a message from Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., addressed to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Karen Hedgecock CC’d. In Lowery’s follow-up dated around 11:44 AM on September 27, 2024, he wrote: “Aaron and Bryce, Hope you’re both well. Following up on the discovery requests we sent over 7/29/24, looks like we’re about a month over time. When can we expect those? If you need extra time, it would help me if you send over the medical documentation you have relating to Ms. Beck’s treatment. Look forward to hearing from you. Best, Steven B. Lowery, Esq. - 502-625-7306 (direct) Reminger Co., L.P.A.” The message confirmed that the requests were overdue by about a month and reiterated the request for an update or the corresponding medical documentation if more time was needed.

In sum, the record reflects a coordinated discovery discussion related to Robin Willis Beck’s case against Danny Wimmer Presents, with prior correspondence on July 29, 2024 attaching DWP’s IRFPDs and authorization forms, and a later September 27, 2024 follow-up indicating the discovery requests were overdue and requesting an estimated timeline or the medical documentation needed to extend the timeline via subpoena if required. The communications involved attorneys Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon of Whaley Law Firm, Steven B. Lowery of Reminger Co., L.P.A., and Karen Hedgecock, with accompanying confidentiality notices and standard contact information.

Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck.

On September 27, 2024, at 11:51:28 AM -0400, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm forwarded an email thread about discovery in the case Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents to Bryce Koon, Sarena Tuttle, and Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine project email address (RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com).

The forwarded chain includes a message from Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., dated Friday, September 27, 2024, at approximately 11:44 AM, addressed to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Karen Hedgecock CC’d. In that note, Lowery writes: “Aaron and Byrce, Hope you’re both well. Following up on the discovery requests we sent over 7/29/24, looks like we’re about a month over time. When can we expect those? If you need extra time, it would help me if you send over the medical documentation you have relating to Ms. Beck’s treatment. Look forward to hearing from you. Best, Steven B. Lowery, Esq. - 502-625-7306 (direct) Reminger Co., L.P.A.”

This message is part of a back-and-forth thread that includes an earlier email from Lowery dated Monday, July 29, 2024, at 12:00 PM, sent to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon with Karen Hedgecock CC’d. The subject line of that email reads: “re DWP Discovery to Ms. Beck - Beck, Robin v. Danny Wimmer Presents.” In that July 29 message, Lowery states: “Aaron and Bryce, Hope all is well. Please find attached (1) DWP’s IRFPDs onto Ms. Beck, with .WORD doc included, and (2) authorizations. If your client does not agree to authorizations for her medical and wage records, please let me know at your earliest convenience so we can begin the subpoena process. Let me know if you have any questions or concerns.” He signs with his professional details, including the firm’s name, contact information, and a note about the attachments.

The thread includes Lowery’s full contact information: Steven B. Lowery, Esq., Attorney at Reminger Co., LPA; direct line 502-625-7306; fax 502-589-5436; mobile 703-517-9480; website www.reminger.com; office address 730 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202; email SLowery@reminger.com. His email signature also contains a confidentiality disclaimer stating that the information is confidential and intended only for the recipient or others authorized to receive it, that disclosure or action in relation to the contents is prohibited if one is not the intended recipient, and that the email has been scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast. The forwarded message also notes the sender’s affiliation with Reminger Co., L.P.A. and reiterates the recipient’s contact at Whaley Law Firm.

The chain also contains the second portion of the July 29 thread listing Aaron Whaley’s and Bryce Koon’s contact details as well as the Whaley Law Firm address (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222) and phone number (502-583-4022). The content of the July 29 message emphasizes that DWP’s IRFPDs to Ms. Beck and the associated authorizations were attached, and that if Ms. Beck does not agree to authorizations for medical and wage records, they should be advised so the subpoena process can begin. The message ends with Lowery inviting any questions or concerns.

In summary, the communications show that discovery requests were sent on July 29, 2024, were reportedly about a month overdue by September 27, 2024, and that Lowery requested an estimate of when the discovery would be produced. He also offered to accept medical documentation related to Ms. Beck’s treatment if additional time was needed. The attached materials referenced in the July 29 email included DWP’s IRFPDs directed at Ms. Beck and medical/wage record authorizations. The correspondence also documents the procedural path toward potential subpoenas if the client did not authorize the release of medical and wage information.

End of note.

On October 4, 2024, at 14:43:21 UTC, Tina Fuqua, a ROI Quality Analyst (tina.fuqua@medicopy.net), sent a file titled “ROBIN BECK .zip” via Box to the recipient sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. The message states that the file contains the medical records you requested and provides the access link: https://medicopy.box.com/s/fcjf2otussqzc4uo978jqqlenx1shggx, with a corresponding View link: https://medicopy.box.com/s/fcjf2otussqzc4uo978jqqlenx1shggx. The email instructs recipients to click “View File” to access the records and explains that the access password will be “MCSI” plus the patient’s four-digit birth year (for example, MCSI1912). It emphasizes that the file should be downloaded because the link will disable after 10 days, and it provides a contact number for assistance: 866.587.6274. The message also includes the same link text in a separate line labeled “View File.”

The email footer contains additional Box-related prompts and links, including a prompt to get the Box mobile app (with a long mobile link), and numerous Box navigation links such as About Box, Edit Notification Settings, Privacy Policy, and others. The footer also lists Box’s address: 900 Jefferson Avenue, Redwood City, CA 94063, USA, and includes a standard unsubscribe line for MediCopy emails.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. The client is Robin Willis Beck, and the matter is Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (re discovery to Ms. Beck).

The correspondence unfolds as a chain of emails among counsel regarding DWP’s discovery for Ms. Beck. On July 29, 2024, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Karen Hedgecock copied, and with the Filevine address for Robin Willis Beck included in the CC. In that message, Lowery advised that attached to the email were (1) DWP’s interrogatory and request for production disclosures onto Ms. Beck, provided in a Word document, and (2) authorizations. He noted that if Ms. Beck does not consent to authorizations for her medical and wage records, he asked to be informed at the earliest opportunity so the subpoena process could be initiated. He closed by inviting any questions or concerns and provided his contact information, including his direct line. The email also contained the standard attorney-client privileged disclaimer, indicating the message was confidential and that any inadvertent receipt should prompt contact with The Whaley Law Firm and caution against disclosure or forwarding.

A subsequent message from Steven B. Lowery, dated September 27, 2024 at 11:45 AM, reaffirmed the status of the discovery requests—those that were sent on July 29, 2024—and noted that the requests were about a month past due. Lowery asked Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon when they could provide the expected responses and added that if additional time was required, they should send the medical documentation relating to Ms. Beck’s treatment to assist in evaluating progress and needs. The message was copied to Karen Hedgecock, continuing the procedural reminder.

Earlier in the timeline, on July 29, 2024, in the same thread, Lowery had stated that attached to his email were (1) DWP’s IRFPDs onto Ms. Beck, with a Word document included, and (2) authorizations. He requested that if Ms. Beck did not agree to authorizations for her medical and wage records, the recipients should inform him as soon as possible so the subpoena process could begin. The communication concluded with an offer to answer questions or concerns and included Lowery’s professional signature and affiliation with Reminger Co., L.P.A., along with the firm’s address and contact information, and the standard disclaimer about confidentiality and restricted use.

On October 10, 2024, at approximately 1:55 PM GMT-04:00, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm sent a response to counsel, including Aaron Whaley and Steven B. Lowery, with Karen Hedgecock and Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine email address also in the correspondence. In this message, Bryce attached Plaintiff’s discovery responses along with the associated notice filed that day. He provided a Dropbox link to the document production: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/zq8y5cyunhcp989xz3fd8/AKakPDHt6bVwFBnN8RF0a_k?rlkey=9fev3zilbvkracbskcf6aq51u&st=tyuregsj&dl=0. Bryce stated that, as discussed, they would supplement these responses as updated medical records and expenses are received. The email included Bryce’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone number 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) and contained the confidentiality disclaimer conventional to such communications, noting the message was intended only for the named recipient and warning against use or disclosure by others, with instruction to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error.

Later that same day, at approximately 7:06 AM, Steven B. Lowery replied to Aaron and Bryce, urging that the case be moved forward. He asked them to confirm whether they could provide the discovery responses within the next ten days. His email, like the others, was signed with his Reminger Co., L.P.A. affiliations and contact details and included the standard disclaimer about confidentiality and authorized recipients.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. The record indicates that Norton Audubon Hospital CMR/CMB was received, with BK awaiting a response to a discharge discussion request, and the material was reviewed for relatedness.

On May 9, 2024, the left ankle MRI was performed and showed a closed avulsion fracture of the distal fibula with delayed healing and ankle effusion. The MRI results, pages 15–16, indicate multiple tears and nonunion of the fibular fracture.

Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. Re: re DWP Discovery to Ms. Beck - Beck, Robin v. Danny Wimmer Presents.

On October 10, 2024, at 1:55 PM, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Steven B. Lowery of Reminger Co., L.P.A., with copies to Karen Hedgecock (Reminger), to the RobinWillisBeck Filevine project email address, and to Sarena Tuttle, regarding DWP discovery to Ms. Beck in the action Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents. The subject noted was the DWP discovery matter. In the body, Bryce attached Plaintiff’s discovery responses along with the associated notice filed that day. He also provided a Dropbox link to the document production: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/zq8y5cyunhcp989xz3fd8/AKakPDHt6bVwFBnN8RF0a_k?rlkey=9fev3zilbvkracbskcf6aq51u&st=tyuregsj&dl=0. Bryce stated that the parties would supplement these responses as updated medical records and expenses are received. He welcomed any questions and signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq. of The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address and contact information. A standard confidentiality disclaimer follow-up noted that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and instructed recipients who received it in error to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to use or forward the information; the disclaimer also stated that no waiver of privilege applies.

Earlier that same day, at 7:06 AM, Steven B. Lowery replied to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, expressing a desire to push the case along and asking to be advised if he could expect the discovery responses over the next ten days.

The thread also contains prior correspondence. On September 27, 2024, Steven B. Lowery sent a message to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Karen Hedgecock copied, in reply to a prior request titled RE: re DWP Discovery to Ms. Beck - Beck, Robin v. Danny Wimmer Presents. Lowery noted that the discovery requests had been sent on July 29, 2024 and that the matter was about a month overdue. He asked when the responses could be expected and added that if extra time was needed, it would help him if the medical documentation relating to Ms. Beck’s treatment could be provided.

Earlier still, on July 29, 2024 at 12:00 PM, Lowery wrote to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, with Karen Hedgecock copied, regarding re DWP Discovery to Ms. Beck. He attached DWP’s IRFPDs onto Ms. Beck, including a Word document, and (2) authorizations. He stated that if the client did not agree to authorizations for medical and wage records, they should inform him at the earliest convenience so they could begin the subpoena process. He invited any questions or concerns. The signature block of this message included Lowery’s Reminger contact details and a standard confidentiality disclaimer, noting that the information was confidential and intended only for the recipient, with a warning against disclosure or action by others, and that Mimecast had scanned the email for viruses.

In sum, the October 2024 communications documented the plaintiff’s discovery responses and associated notices being shared, with a linked dropbox for production, and a continued intent to supplement as medical records and expenses were updated. They also show a back-and-forth timeline in which defense counsel pressed for timely responses and, when needed, for medical documentation to support any potential subpoena process.

Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jeff Cir Crt 24-CI-000532, has been the subject of an email exchange between the Reminger Co., L.P.A. and The Whaley Law Firm regarding discovery and settlement discussions. The matter is identified in the file as a premises-case with the client, Robin Willis Beck.

Chronology of communications:

- December 27, 2024: Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Steven B. Lowery and Karen Hedgecock (cc’ing Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley) to express the intent to move the claim forward as the New Year begins. She indicated an interest in initiating settlement discussions and/or proceeding with Oral Discovery, and she asked whether the opposing side intends to depose Mrs. Willis Beck or if an amicable settlement offer might be forthcoming. The message included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and noted Sarena’s new email address.

- January 2, 2025, 12:01 p.m. (approximately): Steven B. Lowery, Esq., responded to Sarena. He stated that he had reviewed the file and the written discovery provided and informed them that, at this time, his side would like to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition. He requested dates available for Ms. Beck in February and added that, if the opposing office wished to provide a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and evaluation of potential resolution.

- January 2, 2025, 12:08 p.m. (approximately): Sarena replied, thanking Mr. Lowery and confirming that a Demand Package would be forwarded as soon as possible. She noted that, in February, they were available most days except the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th. The message included her signature block with the Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct and office dial numbers, and her new email address.

- January 2, 2025, 5:11 p.m. (approximately): Steven Lowery followed up, thanking Sarena for the outreach. He indicated he had reviewed the file and written discovery and reiterated that Ms. Beck’s deposition should proceed. He asked for February dates for Ms. Beck and reminded that a settlement demand, if provided, would be forwarded to his client for consideration and possible resolution.

- The same day, Steven also proposed a deposition time: Wednesday, February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., and asked whether the deposition should take place at the Whaley Law Firm’s offices or at his own office. He noted that his office is available at 730 W. Main by the Slugger Museum and stated that, if that arrangement worked, they would ensure the matter was noticed accordingly.

- The chain also contains a banner/formatting marker (CGBANNERINDICATOR) and an image banner link included in the January 2, 2025 correspondence. In the body of the exchange, the Whaley Law Firm’s attorney information is reflected, including Sarena Tuttle’s full title and contact details, with the firm’s mailing address and phone numbers, and an explicit note about Sarena’s new email address.

- The record contains the following contact details and signatures: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext. 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). The notes also include standard confidentiality and virus-scanning disclaimers, indicating the information is confidential and intended only for the recipient or others authorized to receive it; unauthorized disclosure or action may be unlawful, with Mimecast Ltd. noted as having scanned the email for viruses and malware. The signature blocks also provide the attorney and firm information for Steven B. Lowery and references to the matter as Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents.

In summary, from late December 2024 through January 2025, the parties discussed and planned for Ms. Beck’s deposition, considered settlement options, and coordinated availability for February, including a proposed deposition date of February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. The Whaley Law Firm indicated they would provide a Demand Package as soon as possible, while Reminger expressed a preference to proceed with the deposition and to receive any settlement demand for consideration. The communications also included logistical details about deposition locations and the parties’ contact information, alongside standard confidentiality disclaimers.

Case: Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson Circuit Court (Jeff Cir Crt), 24-CI-000532. The client is Robin Willis Beck.

Between The Whaley Law Firm and Reminger Co., L.P.A., a series of email communications occurred from late December 2024 through January 2025 regarding settlement discussions, discovery, and the deposition of Mrs. Beck. The lead attorney for The Whaley Law Firm was Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, who also provided her contact information and noted a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The recipient firm was Reminger Co., L.P.A., represented by Steven B. Lowery, Esq., with contact information 502-625-7306 (direct). The emails were sent to and cc’d several individuals, including Karen Hedgecock, Bryce Koon, and Aaron Whaley for the Whaley firm.

The initial outreach occurred on December 27, 2024, when Sarena Tuttle emailed Mr. Lowery and Mrs. Hedgecock (with Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley CC’d) to express the desire to move the claim forward as the new year began. She proposed beginning settlement discussions and/or moving forward with oral discovery, and asked for a determination on whether the defense intended to depose Mrs. Willis Beck or was open to making an offer toward amicable settlement. The communication included standard confidentiality disclaimers stating that the information was confidential and intended solely for the recipient, and noted that the email had been scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd.

On January 2, 2025 at approximately 12:01 PM, Mr. Lowery replied. He indicated that, after reviewing the file and the written discovery, the defense would like to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition. He requested available dates in February and suggested that Ms. Beck’s deposition could be produced at either the Whaley Law Firm’s office or his own office, noting that his office is located at 730 W. Main by the Slugger Museum and that they would arrange notice if that option was chosen. He also stated that if the Whaley firm wished to present a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and evaluation of a potential resolution.

Sarena Tuttle responded on the same day, January 2, 2025, at 12:08 PM, confirming that a Demand Package would be provided as soon as possible. She also stated that the Whaley firm was available most of February, with the exceptions of February 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th. Her signature block reiterated her role and contact information and again included the note about the new email address.

Shortly after, at approximately 12:11 PM, Mr. Lowery replied again, thanking her for the outreach and confirming that he had reviewed the file and the written discovery. He reiterated the desire to proceed with Mrs. Beck’s deposition and again asked for February dates. He also reminded that if the office wished to provide a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and evaluation of potential resolution.

Later that day, at 1:36 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent a final confirming message. She stated that February 19, 2025, at 1:00 PM would be perfect for the deposition, and that they could use Mr. Lowery’s office for the deposition. She indicated she would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the Notice To Take Deposition (NTTD). The message concluded with her thanks.

In summary, the parties agreed to schedule Mrs. Beck’s deposition for February 19, 2025, at 1:00 PM, with the option to hold the deposition at Mr. Lowery’s office if that was convenient. The Whaley Law Firm planned to send a Demand Package and to issue a formal deposition notice to Mrs. Beck following receipt of the NTTD. The exchange also confirmed the parties’ general preference for pursuing settlement discussions or discovery as appropriate, and identified the February availability window for the deposition.

Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. This matter is Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents, Jeff Cir Crt, 24-CI-000532.

In late December 2024, The Whaley Law Firm opened the dialogue by email. On December 27, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Steven B. Lowery and Karen Hedgecock, with Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley copied. She explained that, after the holiday season, the firm wished to move the claim forward and sought to begin settlement discussions and/or proceed with oral discovery. She asked for guidance on whether the defense intended to take the deposition of Mrs. Willis Beck or whether they were open to making an offer toward an amicable settlement. Her message provided her contact details, including the Whaley Law Firm address in Louisville, KY, and noted her new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with direct and office phone numbers.

On January 2, 2025, at 1:36 PM, Sarena Tuttle responded to Steven B. Lowery. She stated that February 19 at 1:00 PM was perfect and that they could use Lowery’s office for the deposition. She indicated that she would send a formal Notice to Take the Deposition of Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the NTTD (Notice to Take Deposition). She also confirmed her intent to forward the formal notice to Mrs. Beck once the NTTD was in hand. The message was copied to Karen Hedgecock, Bryce Koon, and Aaron Whaley, and included Tuttle’s signature and contact information.

Shortly after, on January 2, 2025 at 20:42:01 +0000, Karen Hedgecock of Reminger Co., L.P.A. sent a message noting that a Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck had been attached and that it had just been e-filed with the Court. Hedgecock provided her contact number (502-584-1310) and her affiliation with Reminger Co., L.P.A.

In the exchange that followed, Steven B. Lowery also weighed in on January 2, 2025, offering settlement flexibility. He wrote that, “That said, if your office wishes to provide a settlement demand, I will forward it to my client for consideration and for evaluation of potential resolution.” He closed with his direct line, 502-625-7306, and his Reminger affiliation.

Summary of the core developments: the case remains Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 24-CI-000532. A Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck was filed with the Court, with an anticipated deposition date of February 19 at 1:00 PM to be conducted at the office of the receiving party (as referenced in the February 19 scheduling). The parties discussed both the possibility of proceeding with oral discovery and the potential for an amicable settlement, with a formal notice to Mrs. Beck to be issued following the receipt of the Notice to Take Deposition and the parties’ coordination on scheduling.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jeff Cir Crt 24-CI-000532. Client: Robin Willis Beck.

In late December 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, acting as litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for Robin Willis Beck, reached out to Steven B. Lowery of Reminger Co., L.P.A. and Karen Hedgecock regarding the progress of the claim. She suggested that, as the New Year began, the parties explore settlement discussions and/or move forward with oral discovery, and she asked to be advised whether Reminger intended to take Mrs. Beck’s deposition or if they would be open to an amicable settlement offer.

On January 2, 2025, communications continued to firm up the deposition schedule. At 12:01 p.m., Steven Lowery replied that he had reviewed the file and the written discovery and, at that time, preferred to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition. He asked what February dates would be available for her and noted that, if the office wished to provide a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and potential resolution. Later that same afternoon, at 12:08 p.m., Sarena Tuttle responded that they were available for most of February, with exceptions on the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th, and she indicated they would send a Demand Package as soon as possible. At 12:11 p.m., Lowery followed up, confirming his intent to proceed with the deposition, requesting February dates for Ms. Beck, and noting that he could host the deposition at his office (at 730 W. Main by the Slugger Museum) or that the Whaley Law Firm could host it instead if preferred. He also mentioned that, if the opposing side wished to provide a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and evaluation of potential resolution.

Shortly thereafter, at 1:36 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied that February 19th at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and that they could use Lowery’s office. She stated she would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the Notice to Take Deposition (NTTD). Karen Hedgecock then informed the team, at 3:42 p.m., that a Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck had been attached and filed with the Court. In a follow-up message at 3:44 p.m., Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt and thanked Mrs. Hedgecock, including her contact details and noting Sarena’s new email address.

Meanwhile, on January 2, 2025, the team also coordinated the practical aspects of the deposition. The deposition notice was issued and the Court e-filed the Notice to Take Deposition of Robin Beck, as indicated by Hedgecock’s attachment. The parties' email signatures included the Whaley Law Firm’s information, including Sarena Tuttle’s new email address, and the Whaley team continued to confirm availability and scheduling details.

Finally, on February 17, 2025, Steven Lowery sent a follow-up message noting a growing chance of significant winter weather on Wednesday and proposing that the deposition be conducted via Zoom rather than in person at his office, in order to account for the weather risk and avoid potential rescheduling. The proposed date referenced in the exchange was Wednesday, February 19, 2025, which would be the deposition date previously discussed as February 19 at 1:00 p.m. The message proposed proceeding by Zoom if the other side agreed, with the aim of avoiding delays caused by weather.

In summary, the case of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jeff Cir Crt 24-CI-000532) progressed from settlement discussions and a request to advance to oral discovery in late December 2024, to a formal plan for Ms. Beck’s deposition on February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m., to the filing and notice of the deposition with the court, and, as February approached, consideration of conducting the deposition by Zoom due to anticipated winter weather. The Whaley Law Firm represented Robin Willis Beck, and Reminger Co., L.P.A. represented Danny Wimmer Presents. The deposition notice was filed with the court, and new contact details for Sarena Tuttle were communicated.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

about.relevance: court where deposition notice was filed

The Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents matter, filed in Jeff Cir Court under case number 24-CI-000532, involves the client Robin Willis Beck. The file shows a sequence of discovery and settlement communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Reminger Co., L.P.A. representatives beginning in late December 2024 and continuing through February 2025, focused on whether to depose Ms. Beck and whether to pursue settlement.

On December 27, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, reached out to Steven B. Lowery of Reminger and Karen Hedgecock, with cc’s to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley. In that message, she expressed a desire to move the claim forward as the year turned and asked whether the parties planned to Depose Mrs. Beck or to engage in amicable settlement discussions. She indicated that the firm was ready to begin oral discovery or settlement discussions and asked for guidance on whether the deposition would be pursued. The email included Tuttle’s standard signature with her contact details at The Whaley Law Firm and noted her new email address, along with confidentiality disclaimers stating that the information was confidential and intended only for the recipient, as well as a warning that disclosure or action based on the contents could be unlawful; the Mimecast virus and malware scanning disclaimer was included as well.

On January 2, 2025, Lowery replied that, after reviewing the file and the written discovery, his office would like to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition and asked what dates were available for February. He also offered that if a settlement demand package was provided, he would forward it to his client for consideration and for evaluation of potential resolution.

Sarena Tuttle responded later that same day, noting that they would definitely send a demand package as soon as possible and that, in the meantime, they were available for most of February except for the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th.

Later that day, Tuttle replied again, confirming that February 19th at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and that they could use Lowery’s office. She also stated that she would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the Notice to Take Deposition (NTTD).

Also on January 2, 2025, Karen Hedgecock informed that a Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck had been attached and filed with the Court.

In the same thread, Tuttle, in a subsequent message, again confirmed that February 19th at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and that they could use Lowery’s office. She reiterated that she would send formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the NTTD and thanked Lowery.

By mid-February 2025, the weather outlook prompted reconsideration of the deposition format. On February 16, 2025, Lowery suggested conducting the deposition via Zoom to account for a growing chance of significant winter weather on the scheduled day, rather than holding it in person at his office, in order to avoid potential rescheduling.

The following day, February 17, 2025, Sarena Tuttle replied that Mr. Koon was perfectly fine with proceeding by Zoom in anticipation of weather concerns. She added that if Lowery’s office preferred, his court reporter could send over a Zoom link, and that they would update Mrs. Beck accordingly.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties referenced both deposition scheduling and the potential for settlement discussions, with the possibility of a settlement demand being forwarded for client consideration. The communications include the usual formalities and signatures from both sides, including Sarena Tuttle’s and Steven B. Lowery’s contact details and offices. episodes.natural_language:
In the Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents matter, pending in Jeff Cir Crt 24-CI-000532, the deposition of Robin Beck was first scheduled and discussed through a series of email exchanges between early January and mid-February 2025. The write-up shown here consolidates those communications into a flowing narrative while preserving all persons, dates, decisions, and logistical details.

On January 2, 2025, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., replied to discussions with The Whaley Law Firm regarding the deposition of Ms. Beck. He indicated that he had reviewed the file and the written discovery and stated that the parties would like to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition. He asked what dates in February would work for Ms. Beck and suggested Wednesday, February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m. as a candidate time, noting that the deposition could be produced at the Whaley office or at his own office at 730 W. Main by the Slugger Museum if that arrangement was preferred. He also mentioned the possibility of a settlement demand and offered to forward any such demand to his client for consideration and evaluation of potential resolution. The contemporaneous message signaled that the deposition would be noticed, and he invited the Whaley team to provide dates and proceed with notice if acceptable.

Earlier that same day, the Whaley firm responded with their availability: Mr. Bryce Koon was perfectly fine with scheduling in February given weather considerations, and they were available most of February except for the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th. Sarena M. Tuttle, the Whaley firm’s Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, stated that if the defense wished to have their court reporter send a Zoom link, they would update Mrs. Beck accordingly. In addition, she confirmed they would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the other side’s notice to take deposition (NTTD). Karen Hedgecock of Reminger later advised that a Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck had been attached and filed with the Court.

Later on January 2, 2025, further exchanges solidified the agreed date and location. At 1:36 p.m., Sarena Tuttle wrote that February 19th at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and that they could use the defense’s office, while also noting they would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the NTTD. Steven Lowery followed up at 12:11 p.m. with a practical question: would February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m. work for the Beck deposition, and would she be produced at the Whaley office? He added that his own office remained available at the same time if that arrangement was preferred, and he stated that if the plan worked, the deposition would be noticed. He also reminded that the team would forward a settlement demand if the Whaley office chose to provide one for his client’s consideration.

In the meantime, the Whaley firm provided their contact details and reaffirmed readiness to proceed, with Sarena listing the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and contact information (D: 502-357-9971, O: 502-583-4022 ext. 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; noting the new email address). The January 2 sequence also included Karen Hedgecock’s note that the Notice to Take the Deposition had been attached and filed with the Court.

As the February 19 deposition date approached, the parties began to consider weather contingencies. On February 16, 2025, at 8:14 p.m., Steven B. Lowery sent a message to counsel noting a growing chance of significant winter weather on Wednesday and asking whether the deposition could be conducted via Zoom rather than in person at their office to account for the possibility and avoid potential rescheduling.

The weather concern prompted further confirmation the following day. On February 17, 2025, at 11:48 a.m., Sarena Tuttle affirmed that Mr. Bryce Koon was perfectly fine with this plan given the weather, and she offered that if the defense’s court reporter should send over a Zoom link, they would update Mrs. Beck accordingly. Later that same day, at 4:51 p.m. (as reflected in the email timestamp), Steven Lowery replied that they would reach out to the court reporter to move the deposition to Zoom and to obtain a link, which would be forwarded to Mrs. Beck’s office once received. In the same thread, Sarena reiterated that Mr. Koon was comfortable with proceeding via Zoom due to the anticipated weather and confirmed they would update Mrs. Beck with the Zoom link when available.

In summary, the depositions in this case were initially scheduled for February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., with the option to conduct the deposition at one of the offices (the Whaley office or Lowery’s) and, contingent on the weather and logistical considerations, to use Zoom. After the weather alerts issued by the National Weather Service for Louisville during the week of the deposition, the parties agreed to pivot to a Zoom deposition to avoid rescheduling, with the court reporter to provide a Zoom link to be forwarded to Mrs. Beck and the appropriate counsel once available. The communications also referenced a Demand Package and the possibility of a settlement demand for consideration, and a formal Notice to Take Deposition had been filed with the Court. The exchange documents the coordinated effort among Steven B. Lowery on behalf of Reminger and Sarena M. Tuttle, Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, and Karen Hedgecock of The Whaley Law Firm to schedule and adapt the deposition in light of weather concerns, while preserving the underlying case logistics and deadlines.

Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager) representing Mrs. Beck, and Reminger Co., L.P.A. representing the defense.

In late December 2024, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm reached out to Steven B. Lowery and Karen Hedgecock to move the claim forward.
