She provided her contact information, including her new email address, and signed as Sarena M. Tuttle, with the firm’s Louisville address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and direct lines (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104) and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

On January 2, 2025, Lowery responded that they had reviewed the file and wished to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition, requesting available February dates. He noted that if Whaley wished to provide a settlement demand, he would forward it to his client for consideration and potential resolution. Later that day, Sarena replied that Mrs. Beck’s team was available for most of February, with the exceptions of the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th.

Later on January 2, 2025, Lowery proposed a concrete date and time: Wednesday, February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., suggesting production at Mrs. Beck’s offices and noting that his office was open at 730 W. Main by the Slugger Museum if that location was more convenient. In response, Sarena confirmed that February 19 at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and offered to use Lowery’s office; she also stated that she would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the Notice to Take the Deposition (NTTD). She closed with thanks and her signature and contact information, including the reminder to note her new email address.

Shortly afterward, on January 2, 2025, Karen Hedgecock sent an attached Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck, which had just been e-filed with the Court. Sarena acknowledged receipt of Hedgecock’s message and indicated appreciation. The chain also included the standard disclaimers typical of exchange with opposing counsel, highlighting confidentiality and prohibition against disclosure or action by non-recipients; these disclaimers appeared in the January 2, 2025 communications and noted that the email had been scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd.

Moving into February 2025, the weather became a factor. On February 16, 2025, Steven Lowery warned that a significant winter storm appeared likely to impact Wednesday and proposed conducting the deposition via Zoom rather than in person at their office to avoid potential rescheduling. He indicated that he would forward a Zoom link if proceeding remotely. Sarena, responding later that day, stated that Mr. Koon was comfortable with this plan given the weather and offered to have the court reporter send a Zoom link, noting that they would update Mrs. Beck accordingly.

The following day, February 17, 2025, Lowery acknowledged the weather concerns and confirmed they would move to Zoom, stating that they would reach out to the court reporter to generate a Zoom link and forward it when available. Sarena replied, indicating that they understood and prioritized safety, that they had spoken with Mrs. Beck who was understanding, and that they looked forward to hearing back from Lowery. She signed off with her name, title, and firm contact details, including her new email address.

In sum, the deposit of Robin Beck in the case Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents was scheduled for February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., to be conducted at a location to be determined (initially proposed at Reminger’s office, with Whaley prepared to accommodate). After a Notice to Take Deposition was filed with the Court, and with rising winter weather prompting a shift to a Zoom format, the parties coordinated through mid-February 2025 to ensure the deposition could proceed safely and efficiently, updating Mrs. Beck as needed and maintaining communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Reminger.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents, filed in Jefferson Circuit Court (Jeff Cir Crt), case number 24-CI-000532, the deposition of Robin Beck was scheduled for February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. The Whaley Law Firm, representing Mrs. Beck, and Reminger Co., L.P.A., representing the defense, coordinated the deposition logistics. The initial plan, discussed in early January 2025, was to have the deposition produced on Wednesday, February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m., with production either at the Whaley office or at Steven B. Lowery’s office (Lowery noted he was at an address beginning with 730 W. M, though the full street name was not shown in the message). Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm confirmed that February 19 at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and advised that she would send a formal Notice to Take the Deposition (NTTD) to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the defense’s NTTD.

On January 2, 2025, Karen Hedgecock of Reminger transmitted the Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck, which had been e-filed with the Court, and Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt later that afternoon. Steven Lowery had proposed the date and expressed that his office could accommodate the deposition if needed. Sarena indicated that February 19 at 1:00 p.m. worked and that she would await the formal NTTD. The Whaley firm provided their contact details, and Sarena’s communication reflected her then-current email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

By February 16, 2025, Steven Lowery informed counsel that significant winter weather was increasingly likely for Tuesday night into Wednesday, and suggested conducting the deposition via Zoom instead of in person to avoid potential rescheduling. Sarena Tuttle replied on February 17, 2025, noting that Mr. Koon was agreeable to this change given the weather concerns, and offered that if Steven’s court reporter should send a Zoom link, they would update Mrs. Beck accordingly. Steven responded that they would contact the court reporter to move the deposition to Zoom and would forward the link once available, inviting any questions or concerns in the meantime. Sarena followed with further acknowledgment, stating that they understood the safety concerns and had spoken with Mrs. Beck, who was also understanding; she added that they would look forward to hearing back.

The weather-adjusted plan was finalized, and on February 18, 2025, Karen Hedgecock sent the Zoom deposition details. She wrote: “Good Morning All, Here is the link for the Zoom deposition scheduled for tomorrow at 1pm. Let me know if you have any questions. Thanks.” She provided the complete Zoom meeting information:
- Link: https://magnals.zoom.us/j/92499507129?pwd=BtuiZw7fK6FgXDyWEutaR8Tk4nvR4L.1
- Meeting ID: 924 9950 7129
- Password: 352870
- One tap mobile: +16469313807,,92499507129# US (New York); 8558801246,,92499507129# US Toll-free
- Dial by location: +1 646 931 3807 US (New York); 855 880 1246 US Toll-free
- Meeting ID: 924 9950 7129; Password: 352870
- Find your local number: https://magnals.zoom.us/u/ab6aT0vrxs

Karen also included her contact details: Karen Hedgecock, 502-584-1310 (phone), Reminger Co., L.P.A. Her message followed the earlier communications from Sarena and Steven, which had discussed moving to Zoom and coordinating with the court reporter to ensure the deposition could proceed in light of the winter weather.

Throughout the chain of communications, the participants included:
- The Whaley Law Firm: Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager) and her team, with new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104.
- Reminger Co., L.P.A.: Karen Hedgecock (with the listed phone number 502-584-1310) and Steven B. Lowery, Esq. (direct line 502-625-7306) and Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley as CC recipients.
- The case subject and participants included the deposition of Robin Willis Beck in the matter against Danny Wimmer Presents, with the deposition originally contemplated for in-person attendance at the Whaley office or the defense’s option, but ultimately moved to Zoom due to weather concerns.

In summary, after initial scheduling discussions for February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. and a notice to take the deposition filed with the Court, the plan shifted to a Zoom deposition in response to a winter weather watch. The defense and plaintiffs’ counsel coordinated the Zoom logistics, and on February 18, 2025, the Zoom link and dial-in details were circulated for the deposition (now confirmed as taking place the following day at 1:00 p.m.).

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson Circuit Court, Case No. 24-CI-000532. The client is Robin Willis Beck.

In late 2024 and early 2025, counsel communications focused on scheduling Robin Beck’s deposition in the above-referenced Jefferson Circuit Court case. The deposition was to be taken in February 2025. On December 27, 2024, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., wrote to Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm indicating that they would like to proceed with Ms. Beck’s deposition and asking for dates available in February, and he noted that if a settlement demand would be forthcoming, he would forward it to his client for consideration. In response, on January 2, 2025, Sarena acknowledged the outreach and stated they would send a Demand Package as soon as possible, while noting that they were available for most of February except the 5th, 6th, 12th, and 18th.

Later that same day, Steven suggested scheduling the deposition for Wednesday, February 19, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., asking whether the deposition could be produced at Beck’s offices or at his own office (he noted his office is at 730 W. Main, near the Slugger Museum). Sarena replied that February 19 at 1:00 p.m. was perfect and that they could use the opposing party’s office; she also said she would send a formal notice to Mrs. Beck upon receipt of the Notice to Take the Deposition (NTTD). Karen Hedgecock, with Reminger Co., L.P.A., followed up by attaching a Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck, which had just been e-filed with the Court.

Subsequently, the deposition date remained set for February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m., with the plan to hold it at the offices of the counsel unless otherwise arranged. The parties continued to discuss logistical details, including the possibility of a settlement demand, and they agreed to move forward with the deposition as schedule permitted.

As the date approached, concerns about winter weather emerged. On February 16, 2025, Steven B. Lowery proposed conducting the deposition via Zoom instead of in person at their office in order to guard against weather-related disruptions. On February 17, 2025, Sarena Tuttle responded that Mr. Koon was comfortable with this plan in light of the weather, and she offered to have their court reporter issue a Zoom link and to update Mrs. Beck accordingly. Later that day, Steven acknowledged the weather concerns and reiterated the prudent move to Zoom, and he indicated that he would forward a Zoom link once arranged.

By February 18, 2025, the Zoom arrangement was in place. At 9:33 a.m. that day, Sarena Tuttle sent Karen Hedgecock an email with the Zoom deposition link for the deposition scheduled for the following day at 1:00 p.m., and she asked to be advised if there were any questions. Karen Hedgecock provided the Zoom access details in turn, including:

- Link to join: https://magnals.zoom.us/j/92499507129?pwd=BtuiZw7fK6FgXDyWEutaR8Tk4nvR4L.1
- Meeting ID: 924 9950 7129
- Password: 352870
- One-tap mobile: +16469313807,,92499507129# US (New York)
- Toll-free: 855-880-1246,,92499507129# US
- Dial by location: +1 646 931 3807 US (New York); Toll-free: 855-880-1246 US
- Find your local number: https://magnals.zoom.us/u/ab6aT0vrxs
- The message also lists Karen Hedgecock’s contact information: 502-584-1310 (phone), Reminger Co., L.P.A.

The message thread in the emails shows ongoing coordination among the following individuals and their roles:

- Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note the new email address).
- Steven B. Lowery, Esq., Reminger Co., L.P.A. (direct line listed as 502-625-7306).
- Karen Hedgecock, Reminger Co., L.P.A. (phone 502-584-1310).
- Bryce Koon (whaley law firm), Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), and others were copied on various messages.

Timeline highlights from the communications include:
- December 27, 2024: Steven Lowery expressed a desire to proceed with Beck’s deposition and asked for February dates.
- January 2, 2025 (about 12:01 p.m.; 12:08 p.m.; 12:11 p.m.; and 1:36 p.m. exchanges): The parties discussed scheduling, availability (Beck’s availability mostly in February except 5th, 6th, 12th, 18th), and tentatively scheduled February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. for Beck’s deposition, noting the option to place it at either party’s office.
- January 2, 2025 (3:42 p.m.): Karen Hedgecock attached the Notice to Take the Deposition of Robin Beck, which had been filed with the Court.
- February 16–17, 2025: Weather concerns prompted consideration of Zoom deposition; the parties agreed to proceed by Zoom to avoid rescheduling due to winter storms.
- February 18, 2025 (9:33 a.m. and onward): A Zoom link and access details were circulated for the deposition scheduled for February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m., with Karen Hedgecock and Sarena Tuttle coordinating the access and communication.

In sum, the deposition of Robin Beck in the matter Robin Willis Beck v Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson Circuit Court Case No. 24-CI-000532, was initially set for February 19, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. to be conducted at an office location (Beck’s or counsel’s), with a Notice to Take the Deposition filed. Due to anticipated winter weather, the parties agreed to conduct the deposition via Zoom, and a Zoom meeting was arranged with the meeting details circulated to all counsel and the court reporter. This coordination involved multiple parties, including The Whaley Law Firm and Reminger Co., L.P.A., and included notification of a new email address for Sarena M. Tuttle. All the above details are reflected in the email thread dated December 27, 2024, through February 18–19, 2025.

In the Robin Willis Beck case, identified as 20231026-000089, the parties exchanged a series of communications between The Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group from October 2024 through March 2025. The Whaley Law Firm was represented by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and The Phia Group’s contact was Whitney McClure, a Senior Claim Recovery Specialist. The case file is titled Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023, and the client is Robin Willis Beck. The emails include standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of attorney-client communications, and several messages reference a Filevine project email address connected to Robin Willis Beck.

On October 16, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an email to Whitney McClure with the subject Robin Willis Beck (20231026-000089). In that message, he stated “Please see attached,” and the email carried the usual confidentiality disclaimer. The subject line also included an automated line that read, “You don’t often get email from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com. Learn why this is important.” The Whaley Law Firm signature block followed, listing Bryce Koon’s contact details and firm address in Louisville, Kentucky.

The following day, October 17, 2024, Whitney McClure replied with a brief acknowledgment: “Received. Thank you.” Her message included her signature block identifying her as a Senior Claim Recovery Specialist for The Phia Group, along with the reminder that payments should be mailed to P.O. Box 499, Canton, MA 02021 and should include the case number. The confidentiality disclaimer appeared at the end of her message as well.

Earlier correspondence included additional context in that period: on October 16, 2024, Bryce’s email to Whitney carried the standard disclaimer about privilege and proper handling of the information.

On January 20, 2025, Bryce Koon again wrote to Whitney, requesting: “Please provide me with an updated itemized lien statement at your earliest convenience.” Whitney did not reply in that message, but she did respond a day later with an itemization update.

On January 21, 2025, Whitney McClure replied, informing Bryce that “Itemization is attached,” and providing her contact details again, including the Phia Group’s phone and fax numbers and the same payment mailing instructions. The chain again included the usual confidentiality notices.

In a March 2025 sequence, Bryce sent a message on March 24, 2025 stating that they had finally received records for an August 17, 2024 Heartland Imaging visit, which were listed at the bottom of the ledger. He clarified that this imaging was for the right elbow and was not related to their claim, adding that they had not made any claim regarding the upper extremities.

On March 25, 2025, Bryce’s message carried the formal subject line Re: Robin Willis Beck (20231026-000089) and was addressed to Whitney with a cc to Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine project email address. The body began with “Received. Thank you.”, and Bryce’s signature followed. The chain also included the standard confidentiality notice.

That same day, Whitney McClure replied to the thread with a decla­­ration that “I have removed the claim.” Her message, like the others, included her contact information for The Phia Group and reiterated the payment mailing instructions, along with the familiar confidentiality disclaimer.

In summary, the key facts documented across these communications are: the case identifier 20231026-000089; the parties involved (The Whaley Law Firm and The Phia Group, with Bryce Koon and Whitney McClure as primary contacts); the October 2024 exchange acknowledging attachments; the January 2025 requests for and provision of an updated itemized lien statement; the March 2025 note that an August 17, 2024 Heartland Imaging visit (right elbow imaging) had been documented and deemed unrelated to the claim; and ultimately, on March 25, 2025, the claim was removed. The communications consistently carried standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

This case note concerns the civil matter Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson County, case number 24-CI-000532. The client is Robin Willis Beck. The file identifies the matter as Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023, and references a Filevine project email address associated with RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, corresponding to the Robin Willis Beck Filevine project (09/21/2023). The principal counsel listed are W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, and Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., with copies going to Sarena Tuttle and the Robin Willis Beck Filevine project email.

The first relevant exchange occurred on March 11, 2025, at 11:36 AM. In that message, Bryce Koon, Esq., wrote to Steven B. Lowery, Esq., with Sarena Tuttle and the Robin Willis Beck Filevine project email address copied to the thread, in the subject Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532). Koon asked whether the client was interested in informal settlement negotiations before litigation progressed and expenses increased, requesting a prompt indication if settlement negotiations were desired. The signature block for this message identifies Bryce Koon’s contact details at The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email carried the standard attorney-client privilege notice stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, there is no waiver of privilege, and the information should not be used or forwarded to others not intended to receive it. The message also included a disclaimer noting confidentiality and that the email had been scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd.

On March 24, 2025, at approximately 2:42 PM, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., replied to Bryce. In that message, he said: “Bryce, Appreciate the outreach. I’ve received the transcript and given my folks an update. We have a call on this case next week and I should have an answer for your then about mediation. I will follow up.” Lowery’s contact information in the reply identifies him as with Reminger Co., L.P.A., with a direct line at 502-625-7306. This response was part of an exchange that again included the case caption and subject line noted above, and was copied to the same participants as the March 11 email, including Sarena Tuttle and the Robin Willis Beck Filevine project email address.

The thread continued with a follow-up from Bryce Koon on April 2, 2025. In the message dated Wednesday, April 2, 2025 at 12:01:33 GMT-04:00, Bryce Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Just circling back on this one. Any update appreciated.” The April 2 message again carried Bryce Koon’s signature block listing his firm’s address at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, along with the same phone and fax numbers as in the March 11 message. The email also contained the standard confidentiality/disclaimer notices present in the prior correspondence, including the warning about attorney-client privileged materials and the prohibition on sharing with unintended recipients, as well as a note that the email was scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd.

In sum, the record shows a sequence of three targeted communications between counsel in the Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents matter: an initial inquiry on March 11, 2025 seeking informal settlement negotiations to avoid deeper litigation; a detailed reply on March 24, 2025 confirming receipt of the transcript, indicating a scheduled call the following week to discuss mediation, and promising follow-up; and a subsequent reminder from Bryce Koon on April 2, 2025 seeking any available update, with standard confidentiality and security disclosures attached to the messages.

In the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson County case number 24-CI-000532, the client is Robin Willis Beck. This note documents a sequence of communications between The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel regarding settlement negotiations for Ms. Beck. The case caption and file references indicate the matter began under the heading Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023, with the formal caption “Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532).”

On April 14, 2025, at approximately 1:31 PM, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to the counsel for the other side after review and careful consideration. He stated that they were prepared to demand $50,000 for a full settlement of Ms. Beck’s claim, inclusive of any liens. His signature block identified him as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax number (502) 237-3207. The email also carried a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, acknowledging that no waiver of privilege applies and that the information should not be used or forwarded to others not intended to receive it. The disclaimer appeared in the body of the message.

The chain continued with a follow-up email dated May 1, 2025, at 16:09:04 (4:09 PM) Eastern Time from Bryce Koon to Steven Lowery at Reminger & Reminger’s address, with two CCs: Robin Willis Beck’s SF 09/21/2023 Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle. The subject line referenced the same matter: Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532). In the May 1 message, Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Just following up on this. Any update appreciated.” The May 1 email carried the same standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer as the April 14 message, reiterating that the communication is for the named recipient only and should not be disclosed or used if received in error.

Together, these communications document the case status: as of mid-April 2025, the firm indicated a willingness to demand $50,000 to settle Ms. Beck’s claim in full, including lien considerations; and by early May 2025, counsel was follow­ing up for any update on the matter, with the May 1 message noting the ongoing inquiry and including the designated recipients and CCs.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the email communications in the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson County case number 24-CI-000532, with client Robin Willis Beck. The case caption appears as Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. The primary participants in the correspondence are W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm representing Ms. Beck, and Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A. representing Danny Wimmer Presents (DWP). The subject line in the exchanges reads: “Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532).” The messages were sent between April and May 2025 and included a non-identifying CC to Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine project email address, along with standard attorney-client privilege and confidentiality disclaimers in each message. The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and contact information were listed in Bryce Koon’s signature, and Reminger’s contact details appeared in Steven Lowery’s signature.

On April 14, 2025, Bryce Koon wrote to counsel for the defense after review and careful consideration. He stated that The Whaley Law Firm was prepared to demand fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) for full settlement of Ms. Beck’s claim, including the payment of any liens. He thanked the recipient for their consideration and signaled a desire to move the case forward. This message included a disclaimer noting confidentiality and attorney-client privilege, as did the subsequent messages.

On May 1, 2025, at 4:09 PM, Bryce Koon followed up with counsel, asking for any update on the matter. He again included the standard disclaimer and his contact information.

On May 12, 2025, at 9:59 AM, Bryce Koon sent another message addressing the ongoing status of the demand. He stated that he had not heard back regarding the demand, which he believed to be reasonable and fairly conservative under the circumstances. He indicated openness to scheduling mediation if that was the preferred route, but he emphasized the need to move the case forward and noted that, if mediation were to occur, discovery responses from Ms. Beck would be required beforehand. He asked how counsel wished to proceed. The message carried the same confidentiality disclaimer and the affected contact details.

On May 13, 2025, at 9:42 AM (noted as “9:42?AM” in the record), Steven B. Lowery replied. He thanked Bryce for the follow-up and acknowledged his position regarding mediation if that route were pursued. He explained that the demand had been sent and was currently under discussion, adding that the insurance representative had been on vacation and that DWP was in festival season, making it difficult to set calls. He anticipated providing a response in the coming days. This reply also included the standard privilege disclaimer and Steven Lowery’s signature.

Finally, on May 23, 2025, at 10:29:44 AM (GMT-04:00), Bryce Koon sent a further follow-up: “Good morning Steven, Any updates?” He again included the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer and his firm’s contact information.

In summary, these communications show an initial settlement demand of $50,000 for Ms. Beck’s full settlement including liens on April 14, 2025, followed by repeated follow-ups through May 23, 2025. The defense indicated the demand had been sent and was under discussion, with scheduling delays attributed to an on-vacation insurance representative and DWP’s festival season, and a note that mediation would require discovery responses beforehand if pursued.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an electronic message to Whitney McClure of The Phia Group, with the subject “Re: Robin Willis Beck (20231026-000089)” and CC’d Robin Willis Beck SF 09/21/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address. On March 25, 2025, at 9:28 AM, Bryce Koon replied to Whitney McClure regarding “Robin Willis Beck (20231026-000089)” and CC’d Robin Willis Beck SF 09/21/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address. Also on March 25, 2025, at 9:03? AM, Whitney McClure responded to Bryce with: “Good morning, I have removed the claim.” The message again included Whitney’s contact details, the payment mailing address, and the confidentiality disclaimer.

This is not related to our claim - it is for right elbow imaging. Earlier, on October 17, 2024, at 9:39? AM, Whitney McClure responded to Bryce with: “Received thank you.” The message included Whitney’s contact information and the confidentiality disclaimer.

Throughout these messages, the emails carried the standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimers indicating that the information is intended only for the named recipient and may be attorney-client privileged or protected. The chain shows a pattern of discussions about lien itemization, claims related to the case, and specific records such as the 8/17/24 Heartland Imaging visit, which was clarified as not related to the claim and specifically noted as right elbow imaging with no claims made regarding upper extremities. The communications reflect ongoing litigation, status inquiries, and administrative actions related to itemization, claims, and records for the Robin Willis Beck case.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the email correspondence concerning Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson Circuit Court case number 24-CI-000532, in which the client is Robin Willis Beck. The record includes the case caption, the sender and recipient details, and a sequence of communications from April through June 2025. The June 12, 2025 message is the latest entry, and the CC line in the messages shows Robin Willis Beck’s Filevine project email address. The messages also reflect standard attorney privilege and confidentiality notices common to such communications.

On April 14, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel for the defense regarding the Beck case. After reviewing the matter, Koon stated that they were prepared to demand $50,000 for full settlement of Ms. Beck’s claim, inclusive of any liens. He thanked the recipient for their consideration and expressed hope to hear from them soon. The message included the customary confidentiality and privilege disclaimer, noting that the information was intended only for the named recipient and should not be shared if received in error. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details were listed as 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207.

On May 1, 2025, Bryce Koon sent a brief follow-up message to counsel, stating: “Good afternoon counsel, Just following up on this. Any update appreciated.” The email again included the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On May 12, 2025, Bryce Koon sent a more substantive note to counsel. He said: “Good morning counsel, I haven’t heard back regarding our demand, which I believe to be both reasonable and fairly conservative under the circumstances. While I’m open to scheduling a mediation if that’s the direction you prefer, we do need to move the case forward. If we are going to mediate, I’ll need to get discovery responses from your client beforehand. Please let me know how you’d like to proceed.” This message carried the same confidentiality notice and the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details as before.

On May 13, 2025, Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., replied: “Bryce, Thanks for the follow-up and understood re your position if mediation is requested. The demand has been sent over and is currently under discussion (the insurance rep was on vacation and DWP is in festival season so getting calls set has been complicated). Should have a response for you in the coming days.” The closing signature included Lowery’s direct phone line, 502-625-7306, and reiterated the Reminger firm details. The message also contained the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

On May 23, 2025, Bryce Koon asked: “Good morning Steven, Any updates?” This message, like the others, included the standard confidentiality disclaimer and the Whaley Law Firm contact information.

On May 29, 2025, Steven B. Lowery responded: “Bryce, No update yet – I’ve followed up this morning.” The communication again carried the confidentiality disclaimer and Lowery’s contact details.

On June 10, 2025, Bryce Koon sent another follow-up question, asking for an update, consistent with the ongoing discussion about the case’s status and potential mediation or discovery issues. The message included the usual disclaimer and contact information.

Finally, on June 12, 2025, at 9:57:46 a.m. Eastern Time (GMT-04:00), Bryce Koon sent the most recent inquiry. He asked for dates for the deposition of the client’s corporate representative in September and noted that written discovery would be served in the coming days. This message also included the standard confidentiality disclaimer and the parties’ contact details again. The June 12 communication was CC’d to Robin Willis Beck via her Filevine project email address, RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and explicitly referenced the ongoing scheduling need for the deposition.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. This is the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson 24-CI-000532, and the communication thread concerns an offer to settle and related discovery.

In the latest exchange, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm addressed counsel for Danny Wimmer Presents. On June 30, 2025, he thanked Steven B. Lowery for the prior letter and screenshots, and stated that after reviewing the materials his client respectfully disagrees with the characterization of the conditions of the area in question. Despite that disagreement, to move the matter forward, he indicated that his client was willing to decrease the settlement demand to forty-five thousand dollars ($45,000). He also noted that attached to the message were discovery requests directed to DWP, and invited any questions about those requests. The email concluded with Bryce Koon’s contact information and a standard confidentiality notice stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or use the information.

The email trail shows a broader back-and-forth dating back to May and June 2025. In a June 25, 2025 message, Steven B. Lowery replied that Bryce’s message and attachments served as a response to the parties’ standing demand from April, and that he looked forward to hearing from Bryce and finishing the week well. Lowery also advised that he would be out of the office on vacation the following week, and that any response submitted during his absence would be addressed in the week of July 7.

Earlier in the sequence, on June 19, 2025, Lowery wrote that the “ball is in my court” but that he had been in mediations or depositions all week, and that he would provide a formal response by the end of the day (EOD) Monday, since he had to be in Cleveland the following day.

On June 12, 2025, there were two messages from Lowery. At 10:13 AM, he advised that the other side’s “ball is in my court,” but noted his team would need dates so that they could designate 30.02 representatives, and that he had heard back from his folks and would have a formal response to the client’s demand early next week. Earlier that same day, Bryce Koon replied (9:57:46 AM) requesting dates for the deposition of the opposing party’s corporate representative in September and indicating that written discovery would be served in the coming days. Bryce also included continued contact details and the standard confidentiality notice.

Before that, on June 10, 2025 at 3:55 PM, Bryce asked if there was any update on the matter. He again provided his contact information and the confidentiality notice.

Looking further back, a May 29, 2025 message from Steven Lowery stated there was no update yet, though he had followed up that morning. Bryce had earlier asked for updates on May 23, 2025, at 10:30 AM. In that exchange, Steven and Bryce were coordinating potential mediation and discussing a standing demand; Bryce suggested mediation could be scheduled if that was the preferred route and emphasized the need to obtain discovery responses beforehand if mediation was pursued.

On May 13, 2025, Steven Lowery acknowledged Bryce’s follow-up and indicated that the demand had been sent and was under discussion, noting that the insurance representative was on vacation and DWP was in festival season, which had made scheduling calls difficult. He anticipated a response in the coming days.

Earlier still, on May 12, 2025, Bryce had asked for dates for the deposition of the client’s corporate representative in September and stated that written discovery would be served in the coming days. A companion message from Bryce at 9:57 AM reiterated the request for deposition dates and the anticipated discovery.

Throughout these exchanges, counsel corresponded regarding settlement posture, upcoming depositions, the designation of corporate representatives (including the need for dates and topics to designate 30.02 reps), and the timing of formal responses to settlement demands. The communications reference the case file for Robin Willis Beck SF 09/21/2023 (Filevine project address: RobinWillisBeckZ4295431@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), and reference the parties’ ongoing efforts to resolve the matter with discovery and mediation as possible pathways.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532), the case notes show a sequence of settlement discussions and discovery planning conducted in mid-2025. The client is Robin Willis Beck. The communications occurred between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., with distribution to a Robin Beck Filevine project address. The subject line for the exchange is “Offer to Settle,” and the file is identified as Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023.

The first dated item in this thread is a July 22, 2025 email from Bryce Koon to Steven Lowery. In that message, Bryce follows up on potential deposition dates for Beck’s case and outlines the anticipated deposition topics. He states that the deposition would cover topics identified in the discovery requests, including control and maintenance of the property, any inspections or upkeep performed, the presence or absence of signage or warnings, and Danny Wimmer Presents’ general safety policies for the premises. He also notes that the deposition would address whether any steps were taken to evaluate or document the condition of the premises before or after the incident, and that once a date is confirmed, he would send a formal notice. The message includes Bryce’s firm contact details and a standard confidentiality notice.

Earlier correspondence in the thread shows the ongoing back-and-forth about settlement and discovery. On June 30, 2025, Steven Lowery replied to Bryce’s prior message, thanking him and indicating that he would inform his team and begin written discovery. Lowery added that he would be out of the office that week but would reach out if there was a counteroffer the following week. In the June 30, 2025 exchange, Bryce had sent a message with the subject line “Re: Offer to Settle,” attaching discovery requests directed to Danny Wimmer Presents. In that message, Bryce stated that after reviewing the materials, his side respectfully disagreed with how the conditions of the relevant area were characterized by the opposing side, but in the interest of moving things forward, they were willing to reduce their settlement demand to $45,000. He also noted that discovery requests were attached and asked Lowery to contact him with any questions. The confidentiality disclaimer appears in this and related messages.

Prior to that, on June 25, 2025, Steven Lowery sent a reply regarding settlement. He referenced a letter that provided a response to Beck’s standing demand from April and expressed a willingness to hear back and complete the matter. Lowery also reminded that he would be out of the office the following week, so any responses submitted during that time would be answered in the week of July 7. This message also carried the standard confidentiality notice.

In earlier messages, Steven Lowery indicated that the “ball is in my court” and that he would provide a response by the end of the day Monday, noting that he had to be in Cleveland the next day. He also indicated that his team would prepare dates for Beck’s deposition and that the parties would designate the corporate representative (with a September target) and that written discovery would be served in the coming days. He mentioned needing topics to designate for the corporate representative and suggested that they would have a formal response to Beck’s client’s demand early the following week. Lowery reiterated these points in subsequent messages, including an exchange on June 12, 2025 and a follow-up on June 19, 2025, where he again referenced continuing discussions about dates and topics and noted he would respond by the end of the day due to travel obligations.

Earlier still, on June 12, 2025, Bryce asked for deposition dates for Beck’s corporate representative in September and indicated that written discovery would be served in the coming days. Lowery responded that he had heard back from his side and would have a formal response early the following week, and he mentioned needing topics so that his side could designate 30.02 reps. In his prior message from June 12, Bryce requested dates for the corporate representative’s deposition in September and provided that written discovery would soon be served.

The thread also shows multiple confirmations of receipt and forwarding with the standard attorney-client confidentiality notices. The CC lines in the emails reflect distribution to Robin Willis Beck via the Filevine project address and reference the case file in the Filevine system. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information is listed as 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-365-5043 and fax 502-237-3207. The Reminger firm’s direct line for Steven Lowery is 502-625-7306.

In summary, through May to July 2025, counsel discussed scheduling for Beck’s deposition, the topics to be covered (including property control and maintenance, inspections, warnings/signage, safety policies, and pre- and post-incident condition documentation), and ongoing settlement discussions. The parties exchanged offers and counteroffers, with the plaintiff’s side reducing their demand to $45,000 and with written discovery being prepared and served, while deposition planning and corporate representative topics continued to be coordinated. Bryce’s latest update in July 2025 confirms that he is awaiting dates for Beck’s deposition and that a formal notice would follow once dates are confirmed.

This is a descriptive narrative of the settlement and discovery discussions in the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson 24-CI-000532), with the case file labeled Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023 and the client Robin Willis Beck. The communications, exchanged by email between counsel for the plaintiff and defense, trace a sequence from mid-June through late July 2025, covering written discovery, deposition planning, and a proposed confidential settlement.

The thread begins with Steven B. Lowery of Reminger Co., L.P.A., indicating in mid-June 2025 that the “ball is in my court” but that he had been in mediations or depositions all week and would provide a response by the end of the day Monday, as he would be in Cleveland the following day. On June 12, 2025, he also noted that while they would get some dates, they needed topics so that they could designate a 30(b)(2) or 30.02 representative, and he had heard back from his people that a formal response to the client’s demand would be provided early the following week. By June 19, 2025, Lowery reiterated that he would respond by EOD Monday and acknowledged other commitments, including travel to Cleveland. On June 25, 2025, he posted that the parties’ letter regarding settlement and related enclosures served as a response to the standing demand from April, and he warned that he would be out of the office the following week, with any responses submitted during that time to be addressed in the week of July 7.

Two days later, on June 30, 2025, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Lowery. He acknowledged receipt of Lowery’s letter and screenshots, stated that they disagreed with the defense’s characterization of the area conditions, and, in the interest of moving forward, offered to reduce their demand to $45,000 for settlement. Koon also attached discovery requests to DWP and invited questions. In the same day, Lowery responded that he would let his folks know and that they would begin work on written discovery, adding that he was out that week and would reach out if there was a counteroffer the next week.

Earlier that same day, Bryce Koon had asked for depositions planning, noting that the topics would include those identified in the discovery requests, such as control and maintenance of the property, any inspections or upkeep performed, the presence or absence of signage or warnings, and DWP’s general safety policies on the premises. He indicated that the parties would cover whether any steps had been taken to evaluate or document the condition of the premises before or after the incident, and he committed to sending a formal notice with dates once he received a date back from defense counsel.

On July 22, 2025, Bryce sent a follow-up to Steven Lowery regarding potential deposition dates for the plaintiff. He reiterated that the deposition topics would align with the discovery requests, specifically referencing control and maintenance of the property, inspections or upkeep, signage or warnings, and DWP’s safety policies on the premises, as well as whether steps were taken to evaluate or document the premises’ condition before or after the incident. He stated that once a date was received, he would issue a formal notice.

A key turning point came on July 29, 2025. In the morning, Lowery requested an extension of about two weeks, until August 15, 2025, to provide full written discovery responses, noting that the discovery was presently due "tomorrow." He also sought confirmation that they could designate a corporate representative for the 30(b)(6) deposition and requested Bryce to send a draft notice that would include the formal list of topics, so that designations and firm dates could be finalized, allowing Bryce to finalize the notice and file accordingly. Lowery also indicated that he had authority for one more increase in their settlement offer, proposing $15,000 inclusive of any liens for a full confidential settlement of the plaintiff’s claims, and urged Bryce to take this offer back to his client for consideration. He invited any questions or concerns about these points.

That same day, Bryce Koon responded, agreeing to the extension to August 15 for the defense’s responses. He said he would prepare and send a draft notice with topics and suggested that dates could then be set. He also thanked Lowery for the offer and said he would discuss it with his client and get back to him.

The email chain also includes the standard confidentiality and attorney-client privilege notices typical of each message, indicating that the communications are intended only for the named recipients and that the content may be privileged or protected; recipients who received the messages in error were instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and to refrain from sharing the information with others.

In summary, between June 12 and July 29, 2025, counsel engaged in a back-and-forth about discovery scheduling and responses, the designation and timing of a corporate representative for a 30(b)(6) deposition, the scope of deposition topics tied to the underlying discovery requests, and a tentative settlement position, with a pending extension to August 15, 2025 for discovery responses and a $15,000 settlement offer inclusive of liens proposed by defense counsel. The parties’ counsel and the plaintiff Robin Willis Beck’s file were repeatedly copied on these communications, which were conducted in the context of the Jefferson County case 24-CI-000532. The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville office and contact information appear in the correspondences, and the defense counsel’s Reminger Co., L.P.A. contact details are likewise reflected.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents, Jefferson County, 24-CI-000532, regarding premises liability claims brought by Robin Willis Beck. The client is Robin Willis Beck. The file notes concern the matter as it existed on July 29, 2025, and reflect a sequence of communications between counsel about discovery, depositions, and a possible settlement.

The timeline begins with an email chain dated June 25, 2025, in which Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., informed Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, that he had attached a letter regarding settlement and related enclosures in response to a standing settlement demand from April. He also stated that he would be out of the office the following week and invited further communication as needed.

On June 30, 2025, Bryce Koon replied, acknowledging receipt of materials and stating that his client disagreed with Lowery’s characterization of the conditions at issue. In the interest of moving things forward, Koon indicated that his side was willing to reduce the settlement demand to $45,000. He also noted that discovery requests to Danny Wimmer Presents (DWP) were attached. Later that same day, Lowery responded that he would begin work on written discovery and that he hoped to obtain an extension to August 15, 2025, to provide full responses, since he believed the current deadline was imminent. He also raised questions about the designation of a corporate representative for the 30.02 deposition, requesting Bryce’s consent to a draft notice including a formal list of topics so that designations and firm dates could be finalized, facilitating the filing process. Lowery also indicated that he had authority for one more increase in the settlement offer, proposing $15,000 inclusive of any liens for a full confidential settlement of Beck’s claims, and asked Bryce to take this to his client for consideration.

Earlier communications included a July 22, 2025, note from Bryce to Steven, following up on potential deposition dates for Beck. Bryce outlined the anticipated deposition topics consistent with the discovery requests, including control and maintenance of the property, any inspections or upkeep performed, the presence or absence of signage or warnings, and Danny Wimmer Presents’ general safety policies on the premises. He also indicated that the deposition would cover whether steps were taken to evaluate or document the condition of the premises before or after the incident, and that once a date was confirmed, he would send a formal notice.

A separate thread from June 30, 2025, showed Lowery’s reply confirming readiness to proceed with written discovery and reiterating the two-week extension request to August 15, 2025, while noting he was out that week and would reach out if there was a counteroffer the following week. He also again referenced the ongoing process for a corporate deposition and indicated he would continue to push for a draft topics notice to finalize dates.

In the June 30 exchange, Bryce had previously stated that, in the interest of moving forward, his client would reduce the demand to $45,000 for settlement and that attached discovery requests to DWP would accompany the communication. He did not state any further changes to the settlement figure at that moment.

On June 25, 2025, Lowery’s message referenced an attached letter responding to Beck’s April standing demand and noted that he would be out of the office the next week, signaling a pause or delay in further immediate correspondence.

By July 29, 2025, the parties’ communications escalated the focus on procedural matters and potential settlement. At about 9:45 a.m., Lowery advised Bryce that he sought an extension of about two weeks to August 15, 2025, to complete full responses to Beck’s written discovery. He also requested Bryce’s agreement to designate a corporate representative for deposition purposes and proposed that Bryce send a draft notice that would include a formal topics list, enabling finalization of designations and scheduling. Lowery then reaffirmed that he had authority to push the settlement offer upward, stating that the company would consider an increase to $15,000 as a full confidential settlement amount inclusive of liens, and asked Bryce to discuss this with his client.

Shortly after, Bryce replied that he was agreeable to extending Beck’s client responses to August 15 and that he would provide a draft notice outlining topics, after which dates could be set. He also indicated he would discuss the proposed settlement increase with his client. Bryce provided his firm’s contact details and reminded that the same confidentiality notices would apply to the correspondence.

Shortly thereafter, Steven proposed that Bryce confirm whether RFAs (Requests for Admissions) could also be extended to align with the IRFPDs (interrogatories and requests for production), noting that if Bryce agreed, he would prepare an Agreed Order.

The final exchange on July 29, 2025, at 11:13 a.m., saw Bryce respond simply, “Yes, that is fine,” indicating agreement to extending the RFAs along with the other extensions and the plan for an Agreed Order once the draft notice and topics were finalized.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties’ communications were sent with the usual attorney-client confidentiality notices and included the relevant participants’ contact details and the Robin Willis Beck filevine email address in the CC field for coordination. The overarching arc of these messages shows a coordinated effort to extend discovery timelines, confirm the scope of deposition topics and a corporate representative, and proceed toward a potential confidential settlement while maintaining the option to adjust demands and formalize the process with an Agreed Order.

Case: Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. Client: Robin Willis Beck. In the matter of Robin Willis Beck v. Danny Wimmer Presents (Jefferson County, 24-CI-000532), counsel exchanged a series of emails regarding an Agreed Order (AO) to address discovery requests, including RFAs, and related settlement discussions.

The exchange began with an email from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, dated June 30, 2025. In that message, sent to Steven B. Lowery, Esq., of Reminger Co., L.P.A., Bryce stated, “You may file. Thanks,” and attached the AO for the RFAs and related discovery matters. The email included Bryce’s firm contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. A confidentiality disclaimer followed, noting that the electronic message was intended only for the named recipient and that it may contain attorney-client privileged information; recipients were instructed to contact the firm if the message had been received in error and not to use or forward its contents to others not intended to receive them.

Earlier that day, Steven Lowery had replied to Bryce, indicating that he would inform his team and begin work on written discovery, and that he would reach out if there was a counteroffer the following week.

Also on June 30, 2025, Bryce sent a separate reply that afternoon, to which he wrote, “Counsel, Thank you for your letter and screenshots. We have reviewed the materials and respectfully disagree with your characterization of the conditions of the area in ques”—a sentence that trails off in the record.

The chronology continued on July 22, 2025, when Bryce sent another email to Steven regarding deposition logistics. He was following up on potential deposition dates for the client and described the anticipated deposition topics as those identified in the discovery requests, including, but not limited to, control and maintenance of the property, inspections or upkeep performed, the presence or absence of signage or warnings, and Danny Wimmer Presents’ general policies regarding safety on the premises. He also indicated that the deposition would cover whether steps had been taken to evaluate or document the condition of the premises before or after the incident. Bryce concluded that once he received a date from Steven, he would send a formal notice.

On July 29, 2025, at 9:45 a.m., Steven Lowery wrote again to Bryce with a couple of key points. He requested an extension of written discovery by about two weeks, to August 15, 2025, noting that the current due date was imminent. He also proposed designating a corporate representative for the 30.02 deposition and asked Bryce to send a draft notice that would include a formal topics list, so Steven could finalize designations and firm dates for filing. In addition, Steven advised that he had authority to increase the settlement offer to $15,000, inclusive of any liens, for a full confidential resolution of the client’s claims, and asked Bryce to present this offer to his client for consideration.

A little later that same day, at 11:12 a.m., Steven again wrote to Bryce, asking for confirmation that Bryce agreed to extending the RFAs as well, since the RFAs would tie into the IRFPDs. If Bryce agreed, Steven said he would prepare an Agreed Order. Bryce replied at 11:13 a.m. with, “Yes, that is fine.”

At 11:24 a.m., Steven followed up with a message stating, “Thanks Bryce. Attached is the AO. Let me know if you agree to the filing.” The record then includes the accompanying confidentiality notices customary to these communications.

The correspondence around that time culminating in Bryce’s 12:19 p.m. message dated July 29, 2025, and the subject line referencing the AO, included Bryce’s closing note, “You may file. Thanks,” along with his firm’s contact information and the standard confidentiality disclaimer. The record also contains the initial header indicating the date of that message as Tuesday, July 29, 2025, 12:19:51 GMT-04:00.

In sum, the parties negotiated an Agreed Order to extend written discovery and RFAs, aligned RFAs with the IRFPDs, and contemplated extending the period for a deposition of the corporate representative, while also negotiating a lump-sum settlement offer of $15,000, inclusive of liens, for a full confidential settlement of the client’s claims. The exchange reflects Steve Lowery’s attempt to finalize an Agreed Order and Bryce Koon’s readiness to file the AO, with both sides coordinating deposition topics, dates, and the scope of discovery and settlement. The record incorporates the standard confidentiality provisions seen in each correspondence and documents the contact details for the counsel and firms involved.

I emailed defense counsel about pending discovery. I called the client to update her on the $15,000 offer, and that I want to wait until we see discovery, maybe do some depositions instead of trial date. I think the value is probably between $25,000 and $30,000. She agreed and was pleased.

I estimated the case value to be between $25,000 and $30,000. She agreed with the plan and was pleased.

Robin Willis Beck is the client in the case titled Robin-Willis-Beck-Premise-09-21-2023. On October 27, 2025, at 02:04:22 GMT-04:00, Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm sent an email marked “Re: Robin Willis Beck” to Steven B. Lowery of Reminger Co., L.P.A., with Robin Willis Beck SF 09/21/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address and Kristin M. Bluehs CC’d. In the message, Aaron asked when discovery responses could be expected, noting that while there is an offer that Steven has made, it is difficult to evaluate without the basic pending discovery. He also apologized if the discovery had already been sent and he had missed it.

Steven’s reply to Aaron’s inquiry was originally sent on October 2, 2025 at 2:18 PM (noted in the exchange). In his message, Steven stated that he looked forward to working with Aaron and that there was outstanding discovery to answer for Aaron’s client, which would be delivered in short order. He reported that an increased offer to settle had been made—to $15,000. He explained that, given Ms. Beck’s medicals and the photographs he had submitted showing the general location where she testified to falling that night (which indicated lighting present), he believed the offer to be fair and did not anticipate receiving additional authority. Steven also said he did not recall any response from Aaron’s client. He added that, absent an agreement, they would need to respond to Aaron’s written discovery. Bryce had indicated he wanted a corporate representative deposition but did not submit a proposed topic list. From there, he suggested they would probably need a trial date. He closed by inviting Aaron to share his thoughts and offered to discuss the matter by phone. The message was signed by Steven B. Lowery, Esq., with direct contact at 502-625-7306 and affiliated with Reminger Co., L.P.A.

Earlier still, on September 30, 2025 at 3:01 PM, Aaron had written to Steven and to Robin Willis Beck via the SF Filevine address. In that message, Aaron explained that Bryce was no longer working in his office and that Aaron was taking over the litigation. He noted that the last correspondence between Steven and Bryce appeared to be at the end of July or the first of August and expressed an effort to determine the current status and what steps were needed to move the case forward. Aaron’s signature block followed, listing the Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and the phone number 502-583-4022.

The communications include a standard confidentiality disclaimer from Aaron, indicating that the information in the email is confidential and intended only for the recipient or others authorized to receive it, that disclosure or action based on it by unintended recipients is prohibited, and that the email was scanned for viruses and malware by Mimecast Ltd. The email chain also contains Aaron’s firm’s contact information, reiterating the address and phone number.
